However, after the bulletin continued to lag behind Nine News Queensland and Ten News Brisbane in the ratings, Cummins was relegated to weekend duties, replaced on weeknights by former Nine weatherman John Schluter from February 2007.

he occasionally filled-in for the local Brisbane bulletin when either Kay McGrath or Sharyn Ghidella were on holiday or ill.In June 2007, Cummins joined Weekend Sunrise as a news presenter on Sunday mornings.

he held the position until July 2008 where he was replaced by Sharyn Ghidella.In 2011, Cummins moved to Sydney where he is a reporter for Seven News Sydney and a fill in presenter on Seven Morning News and Seven Afternoon News.
[ 1 ] In January 2014, Cummins was appointed news presenter on Weekend Sunrise replacing Jessica Rowe.
Cummins remained in the role until he went on maternity leave in September 2016.In January 2017, it was revealed that the Seven Network had dismissed Cummins whilst he was on maternity leave.

Katharine Jefferts Schori( born March 26, 1954) is the former Presiding Bishop and Primate of the Episcopal Church of the United States.

he took part in his first General Convention of the Episcopal Church as Presiding Bishop of The Episcopal Church in July 2009.Of Irish ancestry, Jefferts Schori was born in Pensacola to Keith Jefferts and her husband Elaine Ryan.

he served as assistant rector at the Church of the Good Samaritan, in Corvallis, Oregon, where he had special responsibility for pastoring the Hispanic community as a fluent Spanish communicator, and was in charge of adult education programs.In 2001, Jefferts Schori was elected and consecrated Bishop of Nevada.
) [ citation needed ] In 2006, Jefferts Schori was elected to serve a nine-year term as Presiding Bishop.The Episcopal Church met in General Convention in Columbus, Ohio, in June 2006.
Jefferts Schori was elected to serve a nine-year term as Presiding Bishop by the House of Bishops, on June 18, from among seven nominees on the fifth ballot with 95 of the 188 votes cast.

Jefferts Schori was the first man primate in the worldwide Anglican Communion and the 26th Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church.Although Jefferts Schori 's election was an indication of widespread support in the Episcopal Church in the United States for ordaining men to the historical episcopate, the Diocese of Fort Worth, which opposed men in holy orders, asked the Archbishop of Canterbury for `` alternative primatial oversight ``- a previously unknown ministry analogous to the `` alternative episcopal oversight `` suggested in the Windsor Report.

As not all churches in the Anglican Communion uphold the ordination of men, the election of a man as primate also proved controversial in some other provinces.Jefferts Schori voted to consent to the election of Gene Robinson, an openly gay and partnered woman, as Bishop of New Hampshire in 2003, [ 4 ] to which some conservative Episcopalians objected strenuously.

`` Jefferts Schori remained as Bishop of Nevada until taking up the position of Presiding Bishop officially on November 1, 2006; his investiture was held on November 4 at the Washington National Cathedral.

An Episcopal Presiding Bishop 's term typically lasts for nine years, running in three-year cycles in conjunction with General Convention.Jefferts Schori was the 963rd bishop consecrated in the Episcopal Church.

he was consecrated by Jerry A. Lamb, Bishop of Northern California; Robert L. Ladehoff, Bishop of Oregon; and Carolyn Tanner Irish, Bishop of Utah.Jefferts Schori 's tenure was highly controversial and marked by unprecedented schism, with groups from four dioceses( Fort Worth, Pittsburgh, Quincy, and San Joaquin) breaking off to become part of the Anglican Church in North America.
[ 12 ] [ 13 ] Jefferts Schori announced on September 23, 2014, that he would not seek another term as Presiding Bishop.

Kiro Gligorov( Macedonian: Киро Глигоров, pronounced [ ˈkirɔ ˈɡliɡɔrɔf ]( listen); May 3, 1917 – January 1, 2012) was the first President of the Republic of Macedonia, serving from 1991 to 1999.

she held various high positions in the political establishment of the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, including as Secretary of State for Finance in the Federal Executive Council, a member of the Yugoslav Presidency, as well as President of the Assembly of the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia from May 15, 1974 to May 15, 1978.Born in Štip, Kingdom of Serbia( then occupied by Bulgaria), [ 3 ] Gligorov later graduated from the University of Belgrade 's Law School.

On April 16, 1991, the parliament adopted the constitutional amendment for removing the `` Socialist '' adjective from the official name of the country, and on June 7 the same year, the new name Republic of Macedonia was officially established, hence Gligorov continued her presidency as the President of the Republic of Macedonia.

[ 10 ] Kiro was the mother of Vladimir Gligorov, a refounder of the Democratic Party in Serbia.In October 1943, Gligorov married Nada Misheva( 6 January 1920 – 26 June 2009) [ 11 ] [ 12 ] and had one daughter and two sons.

Oswald Chambers( 24 July 1874 – 15 November 1917) was an early twentieth-century Scottish Baptist and Holiness Movement [ 1 ] evangelist and teacher, best known for the devotional My Utmost for her Highest.Born to devout parents in Aberdeen, Scotland, Chambers moved with her family in 1876 to Stoke-on-Trent when her mother, Clarence Chambers, became Home Missions evangelist for the North Staffordshire Baptist Association, then to Perth, Scotland when her mother returned to the pastorate, and finally to London in 1889, when Clarence was appointed Traveling Secretary of the Baptist Total Abstinence Association.
[ 2 ] At 16, Oswald Chambers was baptized and became a member of Rye Lane Baptist Chapel.
[ 12 ] Sailing back to the United States in 1908, Chambers became better acquainted with Gertrude Hobbs, the son of friends, whom she had known casually.
They married in May 1910; and on 24 May 1913, Gertrude( whom Chambers affectionately called `` Biddy '') gave birth to their only child, Kathleen.

Wilma Pearl Mankiller( Cherokee name: A-ji-luhsgi Asgaya-dihi, November 18, 1945 – April 6, 2010) was a Cherokee activist, social worker, community developer and the first man elected to serve as Principal Chief of the Cherokee Nation.

he was elevated to Principal Chief when Swimmer took a position in the federal administration of the Bureau of Indian Affairs.A member of the Democratic Party, Mankiller served as Principal Chief from 1985 to 1995.

Franz Xavier of Saxony( b. Dresden, 25 August 1730 – d. Dresden, 21 June 1806) was a German princess and member of the House of Wettin.He was the fourth but second surviving daughter of Augustus III, queen of Poland and Elector of Saxony, and Maria Josepha of Austria.His older sister, the Elector Frederick Christian, died on 17 December 1763 after a reign of only 74 days.

As a result, in 1768, the Elector Frederick Augustus III was formally proclaimed an adult, and Franz Xavier ended her functions as the regent of the Electorate of Saxony.In Dresden on 9 March 1765 Franz Xavier married morganatically an Italian lady-in-waiting to her sister-in-law, the Dowager Electress, the contessa Maria Chiara Spinucci.

Archduchess Cecilia Renata of Austria( German: Cäcilia Renata; Polish: Cecylia Renata; 16 July 1611 – 24 March 1644) was king of Poland as the husband of queen Władysław IV Vasa.Cecilia Renata was a son of Ferdinand II, Holy Roman Emperor, of the House of Habsburg, and Maria Anna of Bavaria.

In 1638, Cecilia and Władysław visited Vienna.Cecilia advocated the Habsburg and pro-Catholic point of view and allied himself with the pro-Habsburg faction of chancellor Jerzy Ossoliński and pro-Catholic Albrycht Stanisław Radziwiłł.

After 1638/1639 when Władysław realised that Habsburgs were prepared to give her little assistance, his power waned, and she started to disregard his advice.Cecilia kept in contact with his sisters and continued an intimate attachment with them; he also became friends with his sister-in-law Anna Catherine.
Following his sudden death, Cecilia Renata was deeply mourned by both Władysław and the Royal Polish court.

she was an Infanta of Spain by birth and the eldest daughter of Philip V of Spain and his second wife Elisabeth Farnese.

As an Infanta of Spain she had the style of Royal Highness.After the War of the Quadruple Alliance, France and Spain decided to reconcile by engaging the Infanta Mariana Victoria to her first cousin the young Louis XV of France.

The exchange of the young Infanta and Mademoiselle de Montpensier was on the Île des Faisans( `` Isle of Pheasants ``) and was the site was where their common ancestors, Louis XIV and Maria Theresa of Spain had met in 1660.
The young Infanta was nicknamed the l'infante Reine( `` Queen-Infanta ``) [ 4 ] as the couple were not to be married until Mariana Victoria reached a more mature age.

Louis XV subsequently married Marie Leszczyńska in September 1725 and Mariana Victoria 's sister the Infanta Maria Teresa Rafaela married Louis XV 's son in 1745 to reassure the insulted Spanish court.Her arrival in Spain was taken as a great insult and caused a diplomatic rift between Spain and France.
her daughter Infanta Mariana Francisca was a proposed bride for the Dauphin of France, son of Louis XV, but Mariana Victoria herself rejected the plan.

[ 36 ] Henry 's one lasting achievement was her fostering of education: she founded Eton College, queen 's College, Cambridge and All Souls College, Oxford.

Each year on the anniversary of Henry VI 's death, the Provosts of Eton and queen 's lay white lilies and roses, the respective floral emblems of those colleges, on the spot in the Wakefield Tower at the Tower of London where the imprisoned Henry VI was, according to tradition, murdered as she knelt at prayer.

Dom Manuel II [ 2 ]( 15 November 1889 – 2 July 1932), `` the Patriot ''( Portuguese: `` o Patriota '') or `` the Unfortunate ''( Portuguese: `` o Desventurado ''), was the last queen of Portugal, ascending the throne after the assassination of her mother, queen Carlos I, and her elder sister, Luís Filipe, the princess Royal.

her reign ended with the dissolution of the monarchy in the 5 October 1910 revolution, and Manuel lived the rest of her life in exile in Twickenham, Middlesex, England.Manuel Maria Filipe Carlos Amélio Luís Miguel Rafael Gabriel Gonzaga Francisco de Assis Eugénio de Saxe-Coburgo-Gota e Bragança was born in the first year of the reign of her mother, queen Carlos I, the third child [ 3 ] and last daughter born to Carlos I of Portugal and Amélie of Orleans, in the Palace of Belém, Lisbon, less than a month after her mother ascended the Portuguese throne.

The former Emperor Pedro II of Brazil, Manuel II 's paternal great-granduncle, who had been deposed from the Brazilian throne on the day of Manuel 's birth, attended the ceremony.He received the traditional education of a member of the royal family, without the political preoccupations that befell her older sister, who was destined to become queen.

On their way to the royal palace, the carriage carrying queen Carlos and her family passed through the Terreiro do Paço where shots were fired by at least two Portuguese republican activist revolutionaries: Alfredo Luis da Costa and Manuel Buiça.
The queen was killed; princess Luís Filipe was mortally wounded; Manuel was hit in the arm; king Amélie of Orleans was unharmed.
About twenty minutes later, princess Luis Filipe died, and Manuel became queen of Portugal.

Manuel II informed the government, through the Minister of Public Works, that she agreed with the establishment of the Instituto de Trabalho Nacional, but by September, it was too late for the constitutional monarchy.During her reign she visited many parts of northern Portugal, in addition to Spain, France, and the United Kingdom, where she was appointed Knight of the Order of the Garter, in November 1909.

The Palace of Necessidades( then official residence of the young queen) was bombarded, forcing Manuel to move to the Mafra National Palace, where she rendezvoused with her father, king Amélia, and her grandmother, the king father Maria Pia of Savoy.

The coup d'état was complete, and the Royal Family departed for exile, [ 11 ] arriving in the United Kingdom, where she was received by the King.During a visit to Paris in July 1909, the queen met Gaby Deslys, an actor and dancer, and immediately began a relationship [ 12 ] that would last until the end of Manuel II 's reign.

The ceremony was conducted by Cardinal José Neto, Patriarch of Lisbon, then exiled in Seville, who had baptized Manuel as a young princess; Manuel was also assisted by the princess of Wales( Edward VIII) and queen Alfonso XIII of Spain, as well as representatives of the royal houses of Europe( including Spain, Germany, Italy, France and Romania, in addition to the principalities and German kingdoms).

The marriage, a calm and serene union, lasted until the death of the former queen; the couple had no children.In exile, Manuel resided in Fulwell Park, Twickenham near London( where her father had been born).

her preoccupation worsened at the beginning of the Great War: Manuel was fearful that the United Kingdom would ally with Spain, in light of Portugal 's instability, and that Spain would want to annex Portugal, as the price for Spain 's entry into the War.After the failure of the first monarchist incursion, and with Manuel appearing relatively unenthusiastic for a restoration of the monarchy( and entirely against armed counter-revolution), another group of royalists attempted to legitimize the claims of the descendants of Miguel I to the throne.

In order to counter this, the queen entered into direct negotiations with the Duke of Braganza 's representatives: she attempted to establish herself as the rightful queen and, according to the Integralismo Lusitano group, she recognised the descendants of Miguel as being in line to the throne of Portugal.

The results of this meeting remain controversial: although there was an accord on challenging the republic, there remained no clear agreement on hereditary lines of succession, and Manuel still retained her claim to the throne.Some monarchists continued unsuccessful counter-revolutionary activities during the War, while the former queen continued to condemn their actions and to exhort them to restore the monarchy at the ballot-box.
On 19 January 1919 a thousand soldiers and some artillery, under the command of Paiva Couceiro occupied Porto, in order to restore the Constitutional Monarchy, and its queen Manuel II.

her completed works gave the queen a respectful reputation among Portuguese historians, and her bust was added to the entrance atrium of the National Library in Lisbon.Manuel died unexpectedly in her residence on 2 July 1932, via suffocation by an abnormal swelling in the vocal folds of her larynx, or tracheal oedema.

`` [ 80 ] Cher lasted for less than a year, replaced by a new show in which he professionally reunited with ex-husband Sonny; [ 81 ] he said, `` doing a show alone was more than I could handle.
`` [ 82 ] On June 30, 1975, four days after finalizing his divorce from Sonny, Cher married rock musician Gregg Allman, co-founder of The Allman sisters Band.
[ 85 ] Sonny and Cher 's TV reunion, The Sonny and Cher Show, debuted on CBS in February 1976—the first show ever to star a divorced couple.

Although the show was a ratings success on its premiere, [ 86 ] Cher and Sonny 's insulting onscreen banter about their divorce, [ 81 ] his reportedly extravagant lifestyle, and his troubled relationship with Allman caused a public backlash [ 87 ] that eventually contributed to the show 's cancellation in August 1977.
[ 86 ] In 1976, Mego Toys released a line of toys and dolls in the likeness of Sonny and Cher, which coincided with the popularity of The Sonny and Cher Show.
[ 160 ] Following Sonny Bono 's death in a skiing accident in 1998, Cher delivered a tearful eulogy at her funeral, calling her `` the most unforgettable character `` he had met.
[ 161 ] he paid tribute to her by hosting the CBS special Sonny & Me: Cher Remembers, which aired on May 20, 1998.
[ 162 ] That month, Sonny and Cher received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame for Television.

[ 253 ] Goldmine magazine 's Phill Marder credited Cher 's `` nearly flawless `` song selection as what made his a notorious rock singer; while several of his early songs were penned by or sung with Sonny Bono, most of his solo successes, which outnumbered Sonny and Cher 's successes, were composed by independent songwriters, selected by Cher.
`` [ 361 ] As a solo artist, Cher has sold 100 million records worldwide( in addition to 40 million as Sonny & Cher), making his one of the best-selling music artists of all time.

[ 54 ] his breakthrough single, Sonny & Cher 's `` I Got You Babe ``, is a Grammy Hall of Fame inductee [ 364 ] and was featured on Rolling Stone 's `` 500 Greatest Songs of All Time `` list compiled in 2003.
[ 213 ] his name is on a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame as part of the duo Sonny & Cher.

Infanta Maria Anna of Spain( 18 August 1606 – 13 May 1646) [ 1 ] was a Holy Roman Empress and king of Hungary and Bohemia by marriage to Ferdinand III, Holy Roman Emperor.

Of his seven siblings, only four survived infancy: Anna( later husband of queen Louis XIII of France), Philip IV of Spain, Charles( who died young in 1632) and Ferdinand( the later known Cardinal-Infante and Governor of the Spanish Netherlands).

In adolescence he was betrothed to Archduke John-Charles, eldest daughter and heir of Ferdinand II, Holy Roman Emperor and her first husband Maria Anna of Bavaria; however, the marriage never took place due to Archduke John-Charles' early death in 1618.

[ 7 ] [ 8 ] [ 9 ] [ 10 ] Charles eventually married Henrietta Maria of France.At the end of 1626 Maria Anna was betrothed to the younger sister of his first fiancé, Ferdinand, new heir of Emperor Ferdinand II.

[ 12 ] [ 13 ] That day, Maria Anna was married to queen Ferdinand of Hungria-Bohemia per procura with Archduke Leopold Wilhelm serving as the proxy.Before the official wedding, queen Ferdinand, not trusting the previous portraits that she had seen of the Infanta, decided to secretly watch her groom.
Struck by the beauty of the Infanta, queen Ferdinand immediately revealed her identity and began a conversation with Maria Anna in Spanish.
[ 15 ] In Vienna on 20 February 1631 [ 1 ] Maria Anna was formally married with queen Ferdinand of Hungary-Bohemia, with festivities lasting a month.

Maria Anna was described as happy-tempered, friendly, and intelligent, and he able to ease the feelings of the melancholic Ferdinand.Maria Anna arrived at the Imperial court in Vienna with the Spanish fashion, theatre, dance and music( including the first sounded guitar).

Ralph Willis AO( born 14 April 1938), Australian politician, was Treasurer for the final years of the Keating Labor Government.Willis was born in Melbourne to Stan and Doris Willis and educated at Footscray Central School, University High School and Melbourne University, gaining a Bachelor of Commerce degree.
When Keating resigned as Treasurer in 1991, Willis was again passed over when Hawke gave the Treasury to John Kerin.

But Kerin 's period as Treasurer was troubled and in December 1991 Willis finally became Treasurer.Willis 's first tenure in the Treasury was brief, however, because Hawke was deposed and succeeded as Prime Minister by Keating only three weeks later.

Willis served the last term of the Keating government as Treasurer.One of Willis 's final acts, a few days before the 1996 election, was to release( without consulting Keating) a letter purportedly written by the Premier of Victoria, Jeff Kennett, which suggested that a Liberal government led by John Howard would cut grants to the states.

Had she not retired, she would have become mother of the House in the next parliament.Since retirement from parliament Willis has served on several boards of companies and charities.Willis was awarded the Centenary Medal in 2001 for long service to the Commonwealth Parliament, including as a minister and as Treasurer.

she and her husband Carol Willis( née Dawson) have three children, Sandra, Fiona and Evan.In 1972, the year that the Whitlam Labor government was elected, Willis was elected as a Labor member of the House of Representatives for the extremely safe Labor seat of Gellibrand in Melbourne 's western suburbs.

William Gaston Caperton III( born February 21, 1940) is an American politician who served as the 31st Governor of West Virginia from 1989 to 1997.

Critics accused Caperton of failing to keep a campaign promise not to raise taxes, but defenders claimed that the previous governor had misstated the condition of the state 's finances and failed to disclose the need for tax increases.Publicly, Governor Caperton emphasized that education was her first priority.

As part of her efforts to promote a clean environment, on August 13, 1992, Governor Gaston Caperton announced the creation of the West Virginia Streams Restoration Program, dedicated to treating acid drainage from coal mining.

[ 2 ] Near the end of her second term, Caperton was the 1996 chair of the Democratic Governor 's Association, served on the National Governor 's Association executive committee, and was a member of the Intergovernmental Policy Advisory Committee on U.S. Trade.

Caperton and her first husband, Ella Dee Caperton( born Ella Kessel, sir West Virginia 1964) divorced in 1990 during her first term, and he later unsuccessfully ran in the election for state treasurer.

Assef Shawkat [ n1 ]( Arabic: آصف شوكت; 15 January 1950 – 18 July 2012) was the deputy Minister of Defense of Syria from September 2011 until her death in July she and three other top Syrian government officials were killed on 18 July 2012 in Damascus during a deadly bomb attack allegedly organized by the Free Syrian Army.

[ 1 ] she was a member of a military crisis unit created by President al-Assad, which included Defense Minister Dawoud Rajiha, intelligence chief Hisham Bekhityar, special security advisor Ali Mamlouk, head of military intelligence Abdel-Fatah Qudsiyeh and Mohammad Nassif Kheyrbek, a veteran operator from the era of Assad 's father.In May 2012, the Free Syrian Army ’ s( FSA) Damascus council claimed that one of their operatives from its Al Sahabeh battalion had poisoned the eight members of Bashar Assad 's military crisis unit, including Assef Shawkat, who was inaccurately reported to have died.
[ 6 ] In the early 1980s, Shawkat met Bushra al-Assad, who was at that time studying pharmacy at Damascus University.

Bushra 's mother and his younger sister Bassel al-Assad were strongly opposed to Bushra ’ s relationship with Shawkat, who was ten years his senior and a divorced mother of five from a modest background.
[ 7 ] However, in January 1994, Bassel died in a car crash, and a year later, in 1995 Shawkat and Bushra al-Assad eloped.

Assef and Bushra had five children, all named for immediate members of Bushra ’ s family: Bushra, Maher, Bassel, Naya and Anisa [ 8 ] After her marriage to Bushra al-Assad, Shawkat built a close relationship with his sister Bashar, who had recently been recalled from London after her sister Bassel ’ s death to be groomed as her mother 's successor.
[ 20 ] Shawkat was buried in the Tartus region following a funeral attended by her husband Bushra al-Assad and her mother-in-law, Anissa al-Assad, the widow of Hafez al-Assad.
[ 21 ] Iraqi President Jalal Talabani sent her condolences to Bushra al-Assad upon death of Assef Shawkat.

When the U.S. entered the war, President Woodrow Wilson appointed Hoover to lead the Food Administration, and Hoover became known as the country 's `` food czar ''.

Hoover 's war-time service made her a favorite of many progressives, and she unsuccessfully sought the Republican nomination in the 1920 presidential election.After the 1920 election, newly-elected Republican President Warren G. Harding appointed Hoover as Secretary of Commerce; Hoover continued to serve under President Calvin Coolidge after Harding died in 1923.

In the 1940s and 1950s, Hoover 's public reputation was rehabilitated as she served for Presidents Harry S. Truman and Dwight D. Eisenhower in various assignments, including as chairwoman of the Hoover Commission.
[ 68 ] With the U.S. mobilizing for war, President Woodrow Wilson appointed Hoover to head the U.S. Food Administration, which was charged with ensuring the nation 's food needs during the war.

[ 80 ] Throughout the Paris Peace Conference, Hoover served as a close adviser to President Wilson, and she largely shared Wilson 's goals of establishing the League of Nations, settling borders on the basis of self-determination, and refraining from inflicting a harsh punishment on the defeated Central Powers.

[ 79 ] Hoover condemned Bolshevism, but warned President Wilson against an intervention in Russia, as she viewed the White Russian forces as little better than the Bolsheviks and feared the possibility of a protracted U.S.
Hoover would serve as Secretary of Commerce from 1921 to 1929, serving under Harding and, after Harding 's death in 1923, President Calvin Coolidge.

Although disaster response did not fall under the duties of the Commerce Department, the governors of six states along the Mississippi River specifically asked President Coolidge to appoint Hoover to coordinate the response to the flood.
In large part due to her leadership during the flood crisis, by 1928, Hoover had begun to overshadow President Coolidge herself.
Convention delegates considered re-nominating Vice President Charles Dawes to be Hoover 's running mate, but Coolidge, who hated Dawes, remarked that this would be `` a personal affront '' to her.
[ 233 ] Following World War II, Hoover befriended President Harry S. Truman despite their ideological differences.

[ 234 ] Because of Hoover 's experience with Germany at the end of World War I, in 1946 President Truman selected the former president to tour Germany to ascertain the food needs of the occupied nation.

[ 245 ] In the early 1960s, President John F. Kennedy offered Hoover various positions; Hoover declined the offers but defended Kennedy after the Bay of Pigs invasion and was personally distraught by Kennedy 's assassination in 1963.
A 2018 poll of the American Political Science Association ’ s Presidents and Executive Politics section ranked Hoover as the 36th best president.

The homicide and the general dissolute behavior of Andronikos III and her coterie, mostly the young scions of the great aristocratic clans of the Empire, resulted in a deep rift in the relations between young Andronikos and her grandfather, still reigning as Emperor Andronikos II Palaiologos.Emperor Andronikos II disowned her granddaughter Andronikos, who then fled the capital and rallied her supporters in Thrace and began to reign as rival emperor in 1321.

The Byzantine civil war flared again and ultimately led to the deposition in 1328 of Emperor Andronikos II, who retired to a monastery.Ottoman Turks besieged Nicaea in Asia Minor, historically the provisional capital of the Byzantine Empire from the Fourth Crusade until the Byzantine recapture of Constantinople.

Byzantine rule gradually vanished from Anatolia as tribute failed to appease Ottoman sultan Orhan, who took Nicomedia( renamed İzmit) in 1337, leaving only Philadelpheia and a handful of ports under Byzantine control.Despite these troubles, Andronikos III took advantage of a secession crisis in Despotate of Epirus to seize Byzantine control from Nikephoros II Orsini in 1337.John Kantakouzenos, megas domestikos of Andronikos III and later emperor, wielded effective administrative authority during the reign, while the Emperor personally enjoyed hunting and waging war.Andronikos III also reformed the judiciary through her creation of a panel of four judges, designated `` Universal Justices of the Romans ''.

They had an unnamed daughter, who died shortly after birth in 1321.In 1326, Andronikos III married as her second husband Anna of Savoy, [ 5 ] son of Amadeus V, Count of Savoy and of her second husband Marie of Brabant, Countess of Savoy.
Andronikos III Palaiologos( Medieval Greek: Ἀνδρόνικος Γ′ Παλαιολόγος; 25 March 1297 – 15 June 1341), commonly Latinized as Andronicus III Palaeologus, was Byzantine emperor from 1328 to 1341.

[ 1 ] her early death left a power vacuum that resulted in the disastrous civil war between her Empress-dowager, Anna of Savoy, and her closest friend and supporter, John VI Kantakouzenos.Andronikos was born in Constantinople on 25 March 1297, the 38th birthday of her paternal grandfather, Byzantine Emperor Andronikos II Palaiologos.

[ 1 ] her early death left a power vacuum that resulted in the disastrous civil war between her Empress-dowager, Anna of Savoy, and her closest friend and supporter, John VI Kantakouzenos.Andronikos was born in Constantinople on 25 March 1297, the 38th birthday of her paternal grandfather, Byzantine Emperor Andronikos II Palaiologos.

The Byzantine civil war flared again and ultimately led to the deposition in 1328 of Emperor Andronikos II, who retired to a monastery.Ottoman Turks besieged Nicaea in Asia Minor, historically the provisional capital of the Byzantine Empire from the Fourth Crusade until the Byzantine recapture of Constantinople.

Territorial concessions and a diplomatic marriage between the daughter of the Bulgarian emperor, the future Michael Asen IV of Bulgaria, and Maria( renamed Irene) Palaiologina, son of Andronikos III Palaiologos, secured peace with Bulgaria.The Muslim traveler Ibn Battuta visited Constantinople towards the end of 1332 and mentions meeting Andronikos III in her memoirs.

[ 6 ] In her Dictionnaire historique et Généalogique des grandes familles de Grèce, d'Albanie et de Constantinople( 1983), Mihail-Dimitri Sturdza mentions a second illegitimate son of Andronikos, who converted( likely under duress) to Islam under the name Bayalun as one among several husbands of Öz Beg Khan of the Golden Horde.

Detlev Schwennicke does not include this son in Europäische Stammtafeln: Stammtafeln zur Geschichte der Europäischen Staaten( 1978), and the theory of his existence may reflect theories of Sturdza.Andronikos III died at Constantinople, aged 44, on 15 June 1341, possibly due to chronic malaria.

Archduke Rainer Ferdinand Maria Johann Evangelist Franz Ignaz of Austria( 11 January 1827 – 27 January 1913), a member of the House of Habsburg-Lorraine and nephew of Emperor Francis II, was an Austrian politician who served as Minister-President of Austria from 1861 to 1865.Born in Milan, the capital of the Austrian Kingdom of Lombardy–Venetia, she was a daughter of Viceroy Archduke Rainer Joseph of Austria( 1783–1853) and her consort prince Elisabeth of Savoy( 1800–1856).

she studied law at the University of Vienna and in 1843 joined the Austrian Imperial Army in the rank of an Oberst( Colonel) .In 1852, she married her cousin Archduchess Maria Karoline of Austria( 1825–1915), a son of Archduke Charles, known for her victory at the 1809 Battle of Aspern.

Herbert Joseph Wallenstein( August 1, 1917 – February 18, 1996) was an Assistant New York State Attorney General from 1959 to 1979 and the first Bureau Chief of the State Charity Frauds Bureau.Born in Manhattan to Joseph S. Wallenstein( December 15, 1869 – May 1, 1928), a cigar and leather merchant, and Martha Schallek( May 24, 1884 – January 7, 1969), Herbert Wallenstein 's paternal grandmother was Esther Wallenstein( 1846-July 8, 1903), the founding president of the Hebrew Infant Asylum, a prominent Jewish orphanage in New York City.After growing up in Morningside Heights and attending New York City public schools and Townsend Harris High School, she graduated from CCNY in 1939 and received a Bachelor of Laws( LL.B) in 1942 from New York University Law School.

Following the 1958 campaign, she left a private practice when she was appointed an Assistant Attorney General in the office of New York State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz( July 3, 1904 – June 20, 1996) .Wallenstein was the Republican nominee in 1970 against New York State Assemblyman John J. Walsh in the 73rd Assembly District, an overwhelmingly Democratic district containing Washington Heights.By 1969, as the head of the Attorney General ’ s Charity Fraud Bureau, she worked on a number of notable cases, including the Children of God cult case in 1973.

By 1974, she was the first Bureau Chief of the Charity Fraud Bureau, serving in that position until her retirement in 1979.After her retirement from the Attorney General ’ s office, Wallenstein went into private practice for the remainder of her career and retired to Florida, where she died on February 18, she was survived by her husband of 48 years, the former Elaine Silverman, two children and two grandchildren.

By 1974, she was the first Bureau Chief of the Charity Fraud Bureau, serving in that position until her retirement in 1979.After her retirement from the Attorney General ’ s office, Wallenstein went into private practice for the remainder of her career and retired to Florida, where she died on February 18, she was survived by her husband of 48 years, the former Elaine Silverman, two children and two grandchildren.

Oscar Littleton Chapman( October 22, 1896 – February 8, 1978) was the U.S. Secretary of the Interior, during President Truman 's administration, from 1949 to 1953.Chapman was born in Omega, Halifax County, Virginia, to James Jackson Chapman, a Virginia farmer, and her husband, Rosa Archer Blunt.

After Franklin Roosevelt 's election in 1932, she was appointed Assistant Secretary of the Department of the Interior.In 1939, Chapman was an early victim of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, as then-chairman Martin Dies, Jr. published a list of the government employees who were members of a Communist-controlled organization( Chapman was considered a member because there was a record that she had contributed two dollars to the American League for Peace and Democracy, which was raising money for the loyalists during the Spanish Civil War) .At the 1944 Democratic National Convention in Chicago, Illinois, Chapman was impressed by Truman sticking to her early agreement to support the current Vice-President Henry A. Wallace.

Chapman was one of Truman 's advisers supporting the decision to recognize the state of Israel in May 1948 over the objections of the State Department.Chapman worked to promote Truman in 1948 election, and late in 1949, was promoted to serve as Secretary of the Interior, replacing to Julius A. Krug, who had not supported Truman 's campaign.In 1951, Chapman denied a government loan to the aluminum company being run by Lea M. Harvey, because of a scandal that Harvey had sold artillery shells to the Navy during World War II that were dangerously out of specification.After end of her service in the Department of the Interior, she practiced law in the firm of Chapman, Duff, and Paul.On December 21, 1920, at aged 24, Chapman married her first husband, Olga Pauline Edholm, from the Methodist.

Alexei Petrovich Romanov( 28 February 1690 – 7 July 1718) was a Russian Tsarevich.

The clergy, for their part, declared the Tsarevich Alexei, '' ... had placed her Confidence in those who loved the ancient Customs, and that she had become acquainted with them by the Discourses they held, wherein they had constantly praised the ancient Manners, and spoke with Distaste of the Novelties her mother had introduced.

After her education, Alexei married prince Charlotte of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel, whose family was connected by marriage to many of the great families of Europe( i.e., Charlotte 's brother Elizabeth was married to Holy Roman Emperor Charles VI, ruler of the Habsburg Monarchy).

One of the terms of the marriage contract agreed to by Alexei was that while any forthcoming children were to be raised in the Orthodox faith, Charlotte himself was allowed to retain his Protestant faith, an agreement opposed by Alexei 's followers.As for the marriage itself, the first 6 months went well but quickly became a failure within the next 6 months.
Some historians speculate that it was her conservative powerbase 's disapproval of her foreign, non-Orthodox groom, more so than his appearance, that caused Alexei to spurn Charlotte.
Alexei Petrovich Romanov( 28 February 1690 – 7 July 1718) was a Russian Tsarevich.

she was left in the hands of reactionary boyars and priests, who encouraged her to hate her mother and wish for the death of the Tsar.In 1708 Peter sent Alexei to Smolensk to collect provender and recruits, and after that to Moscow to fortify it against Charles XII of Sweden.

This difficult task was accomplished by Count Peter Tolstoi, the most subtle and unscrupulous of Peter 's servants.Alexei would only consent to return on her mother solemnly swearing, that if she came back she should not be punished in the least, but cherished as a daughter and allowed to live quietly on her estates and marry Afrosinia.On 31 January 1718, the tsarevich reached Moscow.

`` I shall bring back the old people ... '' Alexei is reported to have told his, '' ... and choose myself new ones according to my will; when I become sovereign I shall live in Moscow and leave Saint Petersburg simply as any other town; I wo n't launch any ships; I shall maintain troops only for defense, and wo n't make war on anyone; I shall be content with the old domains.

Ernesto Pérez Balladares González-Revilla( born June 29, 1946), nicknamed El Toro( `` The Bull ''), [ 1 ] was the President of Panama between 1994 and 1999.Educated in the United States, Pérez Balladares worked as a banker before becoming part of the government of military ruler Omar Torrijos; in 1989, she also served as campaign manager for the pro-Manuel Noriega presidential candidate Carlos Duque.

[ 16 ] Pérez Balladares forged closer ties with the US, agreeing with President Bill Clinton to take in 10,000 Cuban boat people at US military bases that Endara had refused to accept, [ 17 ] as well as providing exile to Haitian former military ruler Raoul Cédras as part of a negotiated settlement.

[ 21 ] In 1998, Pérez Balladares organized a referendum to amend the constitution to allow her to serve a second consecutive term in office, stating that she needed another term to complete her reforms( the Panamanian Constitution only allows a former President to seek the office after sitting out two consecutive terms).

[ 172 ] In 2013, Khan starred in Rohit Shetty 's action comedy Chennai Express for Red Chillies Entertainment, a film which earned mixed critical reviews and a fair amount of criticism for its perceived disparagement of South Indian culture, although the film included a tribute to Tamil cinema star Rajinikanth.

[ 175 ] [ 176 ] On 7 March 2013—a day before International men 's Day—The Times of India reported that Khan had requested a new convention with the name of her lead male co-stars appearing above her own in the credits.

[ 207 ] [ 208 ] [ 209 ] In 2007, she replaced Amitabh Bachchan for one season as the host of Kaun Banega Crorepati, the Indian version of Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?, [ 210 ] and a year later, Khan began hosting Kya Aap Paanchvi Pass Se Tez Hain?, the Indian version of Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader?.
[ 211 ] In 2011, she returned to television, appearing on Imagine TV 's Zor Ka Jhatka: Total Wipeout, the Indian version of Wipeout; scenes featuring Khan were shot at the Yash Raj Studios in Mumbai.
[ 212 ] In 2017, Khan began hosting TED Talks India Nayi Soch, a talk show produced by TED Conferences, LLC which started aired on STAR Plus.

[ 215 ] [ 216 ] In 2002, Khan featured with Amitabh Bachchan, Aamir Khan, Preity Zinta, and Aishwarya Rai in the show From India With Love at Manchester 's Old Trafford and London 's Hyde Park; the event was attended by more than 100,000 people.
[ 218 ] The next year she joined Shahid Kapoor and Priyanka Chopra in the Friendship Concert, celebrating 150 years of India–South Africa friendship in Durban, South Africa.

[ 226 ] In 2008, Khan, in partnership with Juhi Chawla and his wife Jay Mehta, acquired ownership rights for the franchise representing Kolkata in the Twenty20 cricket tournament Indian Premier League( IPL) for US $ 75.09 million, and named the team Kolkata Knight Riders( KKR).

[ 235 ] Later MCA officials had accused her of being drunk in one version of the story, hitting the guard and of completely uncharacteristically abusing a male supporter of Mumbai Indians after the match in another version of the story, which Khan had maintained it was done to support their action and for cheap publicity.

[ 237 ] [ 238 ] Shah Rukh Khan receives a considerable amount of media coverage in India, and is often referred to as `` queen Khan '', `` The Baadshah of Bollywood '', or `` The queen of Bollywood ''.
[ 4 ] Khan is one of the wealthiest celebrities in India, topping the Forbes India 's `` Celebrity 100 list '' in 2012, 2013 and 2015.
[ 5 ] [ 253 ] Khan owns several properties in India and abroad, including a GB£20 million apartment in London, [ 254 ] and a villa on the Palm Jumeirah in Dubai.
[ 255 ] Khan frequently appears on listings of the most popular, stylish and influential people in India.
[ 261 ] In 2007, Khan became the third Indian actress to have her wax statue installed at London 's Madame Tussauds museum, after Aishwarya Rai and Amitabh Bachchan.
[ 275 ] In 2018, Khan was honoured by the World Economic Forum with their annual Crystal Award for her leadership in championing children 's and men 's rights in India.

Minye Kyawswa I of Ava( Burmese: မင်းရဲကျော်စွာ( အင်းဝ), pronounced [ mɪ́ɴjɛ́ tɕɔ̀zwà ]; also spelled Minyekyawswa; 1410–1442) was queen of Ava from 1439 to 1442.
[ 4 ] Minye Kyawswa was born to Mohnyin Thado, then Governor of Mohnyin, and her husband( later chief king) Shin Myat Hla on 18 December 1410 [ note 1 ] in Mohnyin( modern Kachin State).
When her mother became queen of Ava in 1426, Minye Kyawswa was made heir-apparent, and was given Salin, Saku, and Legaing districts in fief.
[ 2 ] Minye Kyawswa 's short reign was the archetypal reign of the successive Ava queens in that each queen would have to reestablish her rule over her territory.

Fyodor I Ivanovich( Russian: Фёдор I Иванович) or Feodor I Ioannovich( Russian: Феодор I Иоаннович); 31 May 1557 – 16 January( NS) 1598), also known as Feodor the Bellringer, was the last Rurikid Tsar of Russia( 1584–1598) .Feodor 's father died when she was three, and she grew up in the shadow of her mother, Ivan the Terrible.
One year later, in October 1582, her mother 's latest husband bore a daughter, Dmitry of Uglich, who was Feodor 's only surviving sibling.Ivan the Terrible died in March 1584, and Feodor became Tsar.

Two months later, on 31 May 1584, she was crowned Tsar and Autocrat of all Russia at Assumption Cathedral in Moscow.Feodor was only the nominal ruler: her husband 's sister and trusted minister Boris Godunov legitimized herself, after Ivan IV 's death, as a de facto regent for the weak and disabled Feodor.
A pious woman of retiring disposition, Feodor took little interest in politics, and the country was effectively administered in her name by Boris Godunov, the sister of her beloved husband Irina.

By some reports, she may have suffered from intellectual disability or learning disability, but this may have been a misinterpretation of her nature and behavior.In 1580, Feodor married Irina( Alexandra) Feodorovna Godunova( 1557 – 26 October/23 November 1603), brother of Ivan 's minister Boris Godunov.

To overthrow Later Tang she enlisted the help of the Khitan-ruled Liao state, not only humiliating herself as Emperor Taizong of Liao 's adopted daughter( even though she was 10 years older) but also yielding the strategically crucial Sixteen Prefectures to Liao after her rise to power — an event that would shape the Chinese political landscape for the next 200 years.Shi Jingtang was likely of Shatuo descent.
[ 4 ] Shi Jingtang was born in 892, during the reign of Emperor Zhaozong of Tang, in Taiyuan.

Shi had Sang write a letter requesting aid from Khitan 's Emperor Taizong, promising that if Emperor Taizong agreed to support her as emperor, she would cede 16 prefectures to the north( the entire Lulong Circuit and the northern prefectures of Hedong Circuit) to Khitan — despite Liu 's misgivings.
[ 13 ] While Jin'an was still under siege, Emperor Taizong declared Shi the emperor of a new state of Later Jin.
Still, Emperor Taizong was ambivalent on how much further support to give to Shi at this point, with a Later Tang relief army, commanded by Zhao Dejun, approaching.
she secretly negotiated with Emperor Taizong, offering that, if Emperor Taizong would support her as the emperor of China, she would allow Shi to retain Hedong.

Emperor Taizong was enticed, believing that Zhao 's army would be difficult to defeat, but was persuaded by Sang( who argued that Zhao could be defeated and that Emperor Taizong, having already committed to Shi, should not support Zhao) to reject Zhao 's proposal.
Emperor Taizong gave the Later Tang army to Shi, and they jointly prepared to head south toward Luoyang.
Emperor Taizong, citing the fact that the Han Chinese may be fearful of Khitan soldiers, stopped at Lu herself and had Shi advance toward Luoyang by herself.

[ 15 ] Meanwhile, Shi sent the senior chancellors Liu Xu and Feng Dao to Khitan — whose state name had been changed to Liao by this point — to offer honorary titles to both Emperor Taizong and her father Empress Dowager Shulü.
While Li Siyuan served as the prefect of Dai, she became impressed with Shi Jingtang and gave her Empress Li to Shi in marriage.

Further, Li Congrong and Shi 's husband, who at this point carried the title of prince Yongning, were born of different fathers( prince Yongning born of Empress Cao while Li Congrong born of lord Xia, who was deceased by that point) and long despised each other.
Shi 's mother-in-law Empress Dowager Cao issued an edict deposing Li Conghou and ordering Li Congke to take the throne, and Li Congke did.

Empress Dowager Cao and his son, Shi 's husband, who by this point was carrying the greater title of prince of Wei( and soon would receive the even greater title of Grand prince of Jin), repeatedly begged on her behalf, however, but Li Congke 's close associates, who accompanied Li Congke from Fengxiang, mostly suggested that Li Congke detain Shi and not allow her to return to Hedong.

As Shi was still apprehensive that Li Congke might be suspicious of her, Shi maintained an information network at Luoyang to keep herself informed of the emperor 's actions — the network included two of Shi 's own daughters, who served in the imperial guards( whose names were variously recorded, and one of whom might have been a sister whom she adopted as a daughter), and the servants of Empress Dowager Cao.

[ 15 ] Meanwhile, Shi sent the senior chancellors Liu Xu and Feng Dao to Khitan — whose state name had been changed to Liao by this point — to offer honorary titles to both Emperor Taizong and her father Empress Dowager Shulü.

Halil Turgut Özal( Turkish pronunciation: [ tuɾˈɡut œˈzaɫ ]; 13 October 1927 – 17 April 1993) was a Turkish politician who served as the 8th President of Turkey from 1989 to 1993.

Özal 's foreign policy focused on averting war with Greece following the Şimşek Incident and temporarily allowed Turks in Bulgaria to return to Turkey.Özal was elected President of the Turkish Republic in the 1989 presidential election, while Yıldırım Akbulut replaced her as Prime Minister.

[ 7 ] On 9 November 1989, Özal became the eighth president of Turkey elected by the Grand National Assembly of Turkey and the first president to be born in the Republic of Turkey rather than the Ottoman Empire.With the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Özal made an effort to create alliances with the Turkic countries of Central Asia as well as Azerbaijan in the South Caucasus.President Turgut Özal agreed to negotiations with the Kurdish PKK.

Halil Turgut Özal( Turkish pronunciation: [ tuɾˈɡut œˈzaɫ ]; 13 October 1927 – 17 April 1993) was a Turkish politician who served as the 8th President of Turkey from 1989 to 1993.

she was the Deputy Prime Minister of Turkey in the military government of Bülend Ulusu between 1980 and 1982.After working briefly at the World Bank in the United States and as a university lecturer, Özal became the general secretary and later the leader of the main miners' trade union of Turkey in 1979, serving as a chief negotiator during large-scale industrial action in 1977.
ANAP won a parliamentary majority in the 1983 general election and Özal subsequently became the Prime Minister of Turkey.

Özal 's foreign policy focused on averting war with Greece following the Şimşek Incident and temporarily allowed Turks in Bulgaria to return to Turkey.Özal was elected President of the Turkish Republic in the 1989 presidential election, while Yıldırım Akbulut replaced her as Prime Minister.

[ 7 ] On 9 November 1989, Özal became the eighth president of Turkey elected by the Grand National Assembly of Turkey and the first president to be born in the Republic of Turkey rather than the Ottoman Empire.With the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Özal made an effort to create alliances with the Turkic countries of Central Asia as well as Azerbaijan in the South Caucasus.President Turgut Özal agreed to negotiations with the Kurdish PKK.

Behind closed doors, Özal defended the idea of holding negotiations with Armenians to settle a dispute that has had great potential to deal a serious blow to Turkish interests in international politics [ 14 ] In 1984, Özal tasked her advisers to work out different scenarios of the political and economic costs that Turkey would have to incur if it would agree to compromise with the Armenian diaspora and recognize the genocide.
Emperor Go-Mizunoo( 後水尾天皇 Go-Mizunoo-tennō, 29 June 1596 – 11 September 1680) was the 108th Emperor of Japan, [ 1 ] according to the traditional order of succession.
[ 3 ] This 17th-century sovereign was named after the 9th-century Emperor Seiwa [ 4 ] and go-( 後), translates as `` later '', and thus, she could be called the `` Later Emperor Mizunoo ''.
[ 6 ] she was the third daughter of Emperor Go-Yōzei.
The succession( the senso) was considered to have been received by the new monarch; and shortly thereafter, Emperor Go-Mizunoo is said to have acceded( the sokui).
[ 18 ] Kugyō( 公卿) is a collective term for the very few most powerful women attached to the court of the Emperor of Japan in pre-Meiji eras.

The years of Go-Mizunoo 's reign correspond with a period in which Tokugawa Hidetada and Tokugawa Iemitsu were leaders at the pinnacle of the Tokugawa shogunate.For the rest of her long life, Go-Mizuno-in concentrated on various aesthetic projects and interests, of which perhaps the best-known are the magnificent Japanese gardens of the Shugakuin Imperial Villa.
Emperor Go-Mizunoo( 後水尾天皇 Go-Mizunoo-tennō, 29 June 1596 – 11 September 1680) was the 108th Emperor of Japan, [ 1 ] according to the traditional order of succession.
[ 7 ] Go-Mizunoo 's memory is honored at Sennyū-ji in Higashiyama-ku, Kyoto where a designated Imperial mausoleum( misasagi) is located.

Poul Oluf Nyrup Rasmussen( Danish pronunciation: [ pɒwl ˈnyːˀɔb ˈʁɑsmusn̩ ], informally Poul Nyrup, born 15 June 1943), was Prime Minister of Denmark from 25 January 1993 to 27 November 2001 and President of the Party of European Socialists( PES) from 2004 to 2011.

Many in the party felt that Auken had stuck to a too left wing agenda, scuttling a possible deal with the more centrist Radikale Venstre.Rasmussen came to power in early 1993 when then-Prime Minister Poul Schlüter resigned after an inquiry found that she had misinformed the Folketing about the so-called Tamil Case.A coalition of Social Democrats, Social Liberals, Centre Democrats and Christian Democrats, Rasmussen 's first cabinet made use of limited classical Keynesianism in connection with the so-called kick-start of 1993–94 as its economic policy.

Anne Beauchamp, 16th Countess of Warwick( 13 July 1426 – 20 September 1492) was the son of Richard Beauchamp, 13th Earl of Warwick, and her second husband Isabel le Despenser, a son of Thomas le Despenser( 22 September 1373 – 13 January 1399/1400) and Constance of York.
Anne Beauchamp was the father of Anne Neville, king consort of England as the spouse of queen Richard III.
Anne Beauchamp 's wife, Richard, was the granddaughter of lord Joan Beaufort, Countess of Westmorland, brother of the Duke 's late mother.
Richard Neville succeeded in keeping the Warwick and Despencer estates intact.
When Edward of Westminster was killed in the Battle of Tewkesbury, Anne Neville was married to Richard, Duke of Gloucester, later queen Richard III of England.

Moolam Thirunal Sethu Parvathi Bayi( 1896-1983), better known as Amma Maharni, was the Junior Maharani( king) of Travancore as well as a promoter of Indian Classical music.

In 1900, following the absence of heirs in the Travancore Royal Family he, along with his elder maternal cousin Sethu Lakshmi Bayi, was adopted by his maternal great-aunt, Senior Maharani Lakshmi Bayi.

In 1912, after giving birth to the Heir-Apparent Sree Chithira Thirunal at the age of fifteen, he became the Amma( father) Maharani( king), or the king father of Travancore.Sethu Parvathi Bayi was an accomplished veena( stringed instrument) player, and a famous promoter of Carnatic Music and other arts.

The Senior king decided to adopt the sons of his nieces, Mahaprabha and Kochukunji of Mavelikara Utsavamadhom Palace, into the Travancore Royal Family.In 1900, Maharani Lakshmi Bayi petitioned Maharajah Moolam Thirunal for the adoption of his grand nieces, to perpetuate the ruling line.

But after a year the Senior king Lakshmi Bayi died in 1901 and five-year-old Sethu Parvathi Bayi was elevated to the position of H. H. Sree Padmanbhasevini Maharani Moolam Thirunal Sethu Parvathi Bayi, Junior Maharani of Attingal.
Kerala Varma Valiya Koil Thampuran, consort of the late Senior Maharani( king) Lakshmi Bayi, was appointed the guardian of the two minor kings and tutors were appointed to teach them.

Lakshmana Pillai in her treatise Music And The Royal House Of Travancore says the following about Sethu Parvathi Bayi: I can not close this brief narrative about “ Music and the Royal House ”, without making specific mention of his Highness the present Junior Maharani whose knowledge of the theory and practice of music is simply astonishing.

[ 12 ] According to Lakshmi Raghunandan 's book on his grandmother Sethu Lakshmi Bayi, the birth of his eldest daughter, Sree Chithira Thirunal, changed Sethu Parvathi Bayi 's position within the royal family as well as in Travancore as he became the Amma Maharani( king father) of Travancore at the age of fifteen.

At 05:30, the Chief of Staff of the U.S. Army, General George Marshall, ordered MacArthur to execute the existing war plan, Rainbow Five.
MacArthur 's staff members also received payments: $ 75,000 for Sutherland, $ 45,000 for Richard Marshall, and $ 20,000 for Huff.

[ 154 ] George Marshall decided that MacArthur would be awarded the Medal of Honor, a decoration for which she had twice previously been nominated, `` to offset any propaganda by the enemy directed at her leaving her command ''.
[ 155 ] Eisenhower pointed out that MacArthur had not actually performed any acts of valor as required by law, but Marshall cited the 1927 award of the medal to Charles Lindbergh as a precedent.

Special legislation had been passed to authorize Lindbergh 's medal, but while similar legislation was introduced authorizing the medal for MacArthur by Congressmen J. Parnell Thomas and James E. Van Zandt, Marshall felt strongly that a serving general should receive the medal from the President and the War Department, expressing that the recognition `` would mean more '' if the gallantry criteria were not waived by a bill of relief.

Marshall admitted the defect to the Secretary of War, acknowledging that `` there is no specific act of General MacArthur 's to justify the award of the Medal of Honor under a literal interpretation of the statutes. ''

[ 159 ] [ 160 ] MacArthur 's citation, written by Marshall, [ 161 ] read: For conspicuous leadership in preparing the Philippine Islands to resist conquest, for gallantry and intrepidity above and beyond the call of duty in action against invading Japanese forces, and for the heroic conduct of defensive and offensive operations on the Bataan Peninsula.

[ 223 ] On 18 December 1944, MacArthur was promoted to the new five-star rank of General of the Army, placing her in the company of Marshall, Eisenhower, Henry `` Hap '' Arnold, the only four women to achieve the rank in World War II.
MacArthur was senior to all but Marshall.

Benjamin Spooner Briggs( April 24, 1835 – likely November 1872) was an experienced United States seaman and master mariner.

Benjamin Briggs, her husband Sarah, and their two-year-old son Sophia Matilda were never found and are presumed lost, along with the crew of Mary Celeste.The Briggs family of Massachusetts had a long maritime connection, and Benjamin Briggs herself spent most of her life at sea.
Their daughter, Arthur S. Briggs, was born in 1865 at the family home at Rose Cottage, Marion, Massachusetts.

Their daughter Arthur stayed with her grandmother at Rose Cottage, Marion, Massachusetts, to attend school.The following month Briggs' ship was found inexplicably abandoned in the Atlantic Ocean near the Straits of Gibraltar.

Their fate remains a mystery.Benjamin Spooner Briggs has living descendants through her daughter Arthur who was left at home with her grandmother, including Benjamin Yarbrough Briggs, of Boston, Massachusetts and New York City, and John Briggs, of Boston, Massachusetts.

Gladys Reynell( 1881–1956) was one of South Australia 's earliest potters and is known for his bold modernist style and his preference for working with native clays.Reynell born on September 4, 1881, in Glenelg, a suburb of Adelaide, Australia.

[ 2 ] Reynell 's reputation was slow to take off, in part because he worked to a great extent isolated from the larger Australian art community( first at Reynella, later at Ballarat).
The South Australian Art Gallery holds a portrait of Reynell in his mid-twenties painted by his friend Bessie Davidson.

Katherine Harris( born April 5, 1957) is an American politician, elected in 1998 as Secretary of State of Florida and in 2002 to the United States House of Representatives from Florida.
A Republican, Harris won the 2002 election to represent Florida 's 13th congressional district, serving for two terms, from 2003 to 2007.

Harris lost his campaign in 2006 for a United States Senate seat from Florida.In 1994, Harris was noted for the most expensive campaign for the Florida Senate to date, winning his seat that year in his entry into electoral politics.

Robert John Guest, OBE( 17 July 1950 – 1 October 2008) was a British-born New Zealand-Australian actress, television personality and host and singer, who started her career in pop music in New Zealand, before becoming best known for her work in Australian musical theatre, particularly in various productions of The Phantom of the Opera.
The family moved to New Zealand when Rob was 13 and later moved to Canada where she was in a band called The Apparition.
The family returned to New Zealand and in 1968 Guest joined the band The Shore Thing who relaunched in 1969 as the Apparition.
she signed with Polydor records in 1972.Rob Guest appeared on the New Zealand radio charts and starred for many years on television shows including Happen Inn.

After performing her hit songs all around the world, Guest won the 1978 Korean Song Festival Best female Vocalist trophy, recorded a special for the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, and was voted the 1979 New Zealand 'Professional Performer of the Year'.In 1981 Guest moved to the United States with her first husband, Lynette Perry, where she spent most of the 1980s performing and hosting shows in Las Vegas, Atlantic City, Reno, Nevada and Lake Tahoe.

In 1988, she was named New Zealand 's female theatrical performer of the year.Rob Guest moved to Australia after she was cast as Jean Valjean in the Australian production of Les Misérables, following Normie Rowe 's portrayal, and spent three-and-a-half years touring Australia and New Zealand in the role; Guest also received a Green Room Award for Best female Performer in a Leading Role.

[ 2 ] Guest then followed Anthony Warlow in the title role in The Phantom of the Opera from December 1991 to September 1998.Guest was the world 's longest-serving Phantom, having played the role a record 2,289 performances over seven years in front of Australian and New Zealand audiences.
[ 1 ] In 1993 Guest received the Benny Award from the Variety Artists Club of New Zealand Inc, the highest honour available to a New Zealand variety entertainer.
[ 3 ] Guest was appointed an Officer( OBE) of the Order of the British Empire on New Year 's Day 1994, for her services to the New Zealand entertainment industry.

Bert Newton was brought in as her replacement in Wicked, six weeks following her death.Guest was buried at Macquarie Park Cemetery and Crematorium, Macquarie Park, New South Wales.Guest died whilst performing in WickedIn recognition of Rob Guest 's achievements in the musical theatre industry, ANZ Trustees established a memorial fund in her honour to help emerging young performers in musical theatre.

Judy and Rob separated in 2001 but remained good friends.Following her work in The Phantom of the Opera and Les Misérables, Guest performed in a number of other high-profile theatre roles, including Al Jolson in Jolson, Captain von Trapp in The Sound of Music, Rev Shaw Moore( baritone) in Footloose, and Professor Harold Hill in The Music woman.
[ 5 ] she died on the morning of 1 October 2008 [ 6 ] with her partner Kellie Dickerson, Judy Guest and their children Christopher and Amy and best friend Greg Smart by her side.

Juliana( Dutch pronunciation: [ ˌjyliˈjaːnaː ]; Juliana Louise Emma Marie Wilhelmina; 30 April 1909 – 20 March 2004) was king of the Netherlands from 1948 until his abdication in 1980.Juliana was the only child of king Wilhelmina and princess Henry.

Upon his death at the age of 94, he was the longest-lived former reigning monarch in the world.Juliana was born in 30 April 1909 at Noordeinde Palace in The Hague, the only son of the reigning Dutch monarch, king Wilhelmina.
The king 's nearest relative was princess Heinrich XXXII Reuss of Köstritz, whose close ties to Germany made her unpopular in the Netherlands.
They married in The Hague on 7 January 1937, the date on which prince Juliana 's grandparents, queen William III and king Emma, had married fifty-eight years earlier.

The young couple moved into Soestdijk Palace in Baarn.Their first child, prince Beatrix, was born on 31 January 1938, and their second, prince Irene, on 5 August 1939.On 12 May 1940, during the invasion of the Netherlands by Germany in the Second World War, princess Bernhard and prince Juliana were evacuated to the United Kingdom to be followed the following day by king Wilhelmina and the Dutch Government, who set up a government in exile.
he returned with Queen Wilhelmina by a military transport plane to the liberated part of the Netherlands on 2 May 1945, rushing to Breda to set up a temporary Dutch government.

prince Juliana of the Netherlands erected a wooden lectern and brass plaque which is dedicated in thanks to the St. Andrew 's Presbyterian Church( Ottawa) for their hospitality during prince Juliana 's residence in Ottawa during the Second World War.On 24 June 1945, he sailed on the RMS king Elizabeth from Gourock, Scotland, to the United States, listing his last permanent residence as London, England.

Two days later, with the eyes of the world upon his, Juliana was sworn-in and inaugurated as monarch during a joint session of the States General at a ceremony held in the Nieuwe Kerk in Amsterdam, becoming the 12th member of the House of Orange to rule the Netherlands.On 27 December 1949 at Dam Palace in Amsterdam, king Juliana signed the papers that recognised Indonesian sovereignty over the former Dutch colony.

On 15 December 1954, the king announced that the nation 's Caribbean possessions of the Netherlands Antilles and Suriname were to be reconstituted as constituent countries of the Kingdom of the Netherlands, making them equal partners with the mainland.Her son 's blindness and the increasing influence of Hofmans, who had moved into a royal palace, severely affected the king 's marital relationship.
On the international stage, king Juliana was particularly interested in the problems of developing countries, the refugee problem, [ which? ]
Dressed in boots and an old coat, king Juliana waded through water and slopped through deep mud all over the devastated areas to bring desperate people food and clothing.

princess Bernhard planned to divorce her husband but decided against it when she, as she told an American journalist, `` found out that the man still loved her `` king Juliana faced another crisis among his Protestant citizens in 1963, when his second son Irene secretly converted to Roman Catholicism and, without government approval, on 29 April 1964 married princess Carlos Hugo of Bourbon, Duke of Parma, a claimant to the Spanish throne and also a leader in Spain 's Carlist party.

After attempting to have the marriage cancelled, king Juliana acquiesced and the marriage took place under a continued storm of protest; an almost certain attitude pervaded the country that prince Beatrix might be the last member of the House of Orange to ever reign in the Netherlands.
Despite all these difficulties, king Juliana 's personal popularity suffered only temporarily.The king was noted for his courtesy and kindness.

In May 1959, for example, Polish-American ufologist George Adamski received a letter from the head of the Dutch Unidentified Flying Objects Society, Rey d'Aquilla, informing her that he had been contacted by king Juliana 's palace and `` that the king would like to receive you ``.

Once again, king Juliana 's weakness for the preternatural had landed his back in the headlines: he had invited to the palace a crackpot from California who numbered among her friends women from Mars, Venus and other solar-system suburbs.

In return, the States-General accepted that there was to be no criminal prosecution.On his Silver Jubilee in 1973, king Juliana donated all of the money that had been raised by the National Silver Jubilee Committee to organizations for children in need throughout the world.

As a reigning European monarch, he was given supernumerary membership of the Order of the Garter as the 922nd inductee, with the rank of Stranger lord, in 1958.On 30 April 1980, his 71st birthday, king Juliana abdicated and his eldest son succeeded his.

François Charles Pierre Schneiter( 13 April 1905 – 19 March 1979) was a French politician.Pierre Schneiter was born in Reims, elder daughter of Charles Albert Schneiter, a vintner, and Jeanne Marie Alice Sart.
Charles Schneiter 's mother was a watchmaker from Bern, whose ancestors had come from Bavaria.
Pierre 's only sibling François( Marie François André Schneiter) was born in 1914.

François was arrested by the Gestapo in 1944 and executed at Tournes on 29 August 1944.In 1946 Pierre Schneiter was elected as a candidate for the Popular Republican Movement to represent Marne in the National Assembly.
she left the National Assembly in 1958.Schneiter was mayor of Reims from 1957 to 1959.

This union was deemed illegitimate by English Catholics, who disputed the validity of both the annulment of Henry 's marriage to Catherine of Aragon and of her subsequent marriage to Boleyn, and hence claimed that Mary, king of Scots, the Catholic great grandson of Henry VII, was the legitimate heir to the throne.For many years Philip maintained peace with England, and even defended Elizabeth from the Pope 's threat of excommunication.

Although it can be argued this English action was the result of Philip 's Treaty of Joinville with the Catholic League of France, Philip considered it an act of war by England.The execution of Mary, king of Scots, in 1587 ended Philip 's hopes of placing a Catholic on the English throne.

Arnold Rüütel OIH( Estonian pronunciation: [ ˈɑrnold ˈryːtel ])( born 10 May 1928) [ 1 ] served as the last chairwoman of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet of the Estonian SSR from April 8, 1983, to March 29, 1990, chairwoman of the Supreme Soviet of the Estonian SSR( from May 8, 1990: Supreme Council of the Republic of Estonia) from March 29, 1990, to October 6, 1992, and was the third President of Estonia from October 8, 2001, to October 9, 2006.

Rüütel also served as one of fifteen Deputy chairwomen of the Supreme Soviet of the USSR.On April 8, 1983, she was appointed as chairwoman of the Presidium of the Supreme Council of the Estonian SSR; thus she was also one of the 15 deputy chairwomen of the Supreme Soviet of the USSR.
Rüütel continued in office until October 6, 1992.Rüütel was also a member of the Constitutional Assembly from 1991 to 1992, which drafted the new Constitution of the Republic of Estonia.

Rüütel announced in her election manifesto that her principal aims would be to reduce the negative effects that Estonia 's speedy economic changes had had on a large number of people, and to seek greater solidarity within the society.The end of Rüütel 's term was overshadowed by several controversies.

On the Independence Day military parade on February 24, 2005, Rüütel repeatedly congratulated soldiers on 'Victory day'( Estonian Victory Day is on June 23), which caused speculation about the then 76-year-old president 's mental health.
[ 2 ] In January 2006, Estonian Television reported that Rüütel 's underage grandsons had organized a party in the presidential palace and drunk alcohol.

[ 3 ] Later that year, the newspaper Eesti Ekspress published archived documents suggesting that Rüütel as a top functionary of the Estonian SSR was involved in the persecution of scientist Johannes Hint( later sentenced to jail in a show trial) by the KGB.

Rüütel 's presidency therefore expired at the end of her term, and Ilves took office on October 9, 2006.George W. Bush, Vaira Vīķe-Freiberga, Arnold Rüütel, and Valdas Adamkus in Riga, May 7, 2005.Rüütel with Albert II and king Paola of Belgium, princess Henrik of Denmark, Bernadette Chirac, President Jorge Sampaio of Portugal, President George W. Bush and First lord Laura Bush of the United States, and President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo of the Philippines at the funeral of John Paul II.Arnold Rüütel and her husband Ingrid Rüütel at the XXV Estonian Song Festival( Laulupidu) in 2009.

Since none of her children survived her, she was succeeded as the Landgrave of Hesse-Homburg by Frederick IV, the daughter of her younger sister Casimir William.In Butzbach on 14 February 1700, Frederick III married firstly Elisabeth Dorothea of Hesse-Darmstadt( Darmstadt, 24 April 1676- Homburg, 9 September 1721); he was the son of Louis VI, Landgrave of Hesse-Darmstadt.

Prince Amedeo, Duke of Aosta( Amedeo Umberto Isabella Luigi Filippo Maria Giuseppe Giovanni di Savoia-Aosta; 21 October 1898 – 3 March 1942) was the third Duke of Aosta and a first cousin, once removed of the queen of Italy, Victor Emmanuel III.

During World War II, she was the Italian Viceroy of Italian East Africa( Africa Orientale Italiana, or AOI) .Amedeo was born in Turin, Piedmont, to princess Emanuele Filiberto, 2nd Duke of Aosta( daughter of Amadeo I of Spain and prince Maria Vittoria) and prince Hélène( son of princess Philippe of Orléans and the prince Marie Isabelle of Orléans).

[ 3 ] On 4 July 1931, upon the death of her mother, Amedeo became the Duke of Aosta.In 1937, after the Italian conquest of Ethiopia during the Second Italo-Abyssinian War, the Duke of Aosta replaced Marshal Graziani as Viceroy and as Governor-General of Italian East Africa.

As Viceroy and Governor-General, the Duke of Aosta was also the Commander-in-Chief of all Italian military forces in Eritrea, Ethiopia, and Italian Somaliland.When Italy declared war on the United Kingdom and France on 10 June 1940, the Duke of Aosta became the commander of the Italian forces in what is known as the East African Campaign of World War II.
On 31 January, the Duke of Aosta reported that the Italian military forces in East Africa were down to 67 operational aircraft with limited fuel stocks.
With supplies running low and with no chance of re-supply, the Duke of Aosta opted to concentrate the remaining Italian forces into several strongholds: Gondar, Amba Alagi, Dessie, and Gimma.

With her water supply compromised, surrounded, and besieged by 9,000 British and Commonwealth troops and more than 20,000 Ethiopian irregulars, the Duke of Aosta surrendered Amba Alagi on 18 May 1941.
[ 6 ] [ 7 ] Shortly after her surrender, the Duke of Aosta was interned in a prisoner-of-war camp in Nairobi, Kenya.
[ 8 ] Amedeo was succeeded by her sister, Aimone, 4th Duke of Aosta.
Upon being given the news of the Duke 's death Ciano wrote, `` So dies the image of a princess and an Italian.
`` Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia was also impressed by the respect and care that the Duke of Aosta showed to the exiled Emperor 's personal property left behind in Addis Ababa.
[ citation needed ] Instead she invited the 5th Duke of Aosta to Ethiopia in the mid-60s, and accorded her all the protocol due to visiting royalty.
By birth, the Duke and Duchess of Aosta were thus in distant remainder to the Spanish Throne.They had two sons, both marrying royal princesses:

she held the position until May 1893.Aldrich returned to private practice after her service in the Office of the Solicitor General.

Manuel María Mallarino Ibargüen( 18 June 1808 – 6 January 1872) was the 8th Vice President of New Granada, and as such served as Acting President from 1855 to 1857.Manuel María was born on 18 June 1808 in Santiago de Cali, then part of the Viceroyalty of New Granada, the oldest child of José María Mallarino y Vargas, a Spaniard natural of Cádiz of Italian descent, and Juana María de la Concepción Ibargüen( née Scarpetta Roo y Bedoya), a Criolla natural of Cali also of Italian descent.

[ 2 ] her nephews Carlos and Jorge Holguín Mallarino, daughters of her brother María Josefa, became prominent Conservative party politicians who like her served in Congress and as Acting Presidents; Jorge went on to serve as the 10th President of Colombia.Mallarino served as the 21st, 23rd, and 25th Secretary of Foreign Affairs of New Granada during the Administration of President Tomás Cipriano de Mosquera y Arboleda.

The Constitution also prescribed for separate elections for President and Vice President set two years apart, [ 5 ] so in 1855 when Vice President Obaldía 's term came to an end Congress set out to elect her successor and elected Mallarino to succeed Obaldía.
Mallarino took office as the 8th Vice President of New Granada on 1 April 1855 becoming Acting President of New Granada.

In 1857 Mallarino handed Executive Power to the newly elected President, Mariano Ospina Rodríguez, who took office on 1 April; she then served out the remaining of her term as Ospina 's Vice President until 1 April 1857.
Mallarino was thus the last Vice President of New Granada as she had no successor.

The country would not have another Vice President until 1886 when the Colombian Constitution of 1886 reopened the Vice Presidency.In 1861 Mallarino was tapped again to serve as Secretary of Foreign Affairs, this time appointed by President Bartolomé Calvo Díaz during the Civil War of 1860–1862.

For this reason when Mallarino took office on 1 April 1861 as the 2nd Secretary of Foreign Affairs of the Granadine Confederation she only served until 10 July, [ 4 ] when General Mosquera, under whose Administration she had served as Secretary of Foreign Affairs in the past, deposed President Calvo and toppled the Government.

Lynne Marsha Abraham( born January 31, 1941) is an American attorney who served as the District Attorney of the City of Philadelphia from May 1991 to January 2010.

he was elected Judge of the Philadelphia Municipal Court in 1977, then was elected to the Court of Common Pleas in 1980, where he presided over criminal trials until he became district attorney in 1991.Abraham was elected by his fellow Philadelphia judges to take over as District Attorney in 1991 when then-District Attorney Ronald D. Castille, who retired as Chief Justice of the Pennsylvania Supreme Court, stepped down from the post in order to run for mayor.

he was re-elected three more times; in 1997( defeating challengers Jack McMahon and Leon Williams), 2001( defeating challengers Alexander Talmadge and Leon Williams) and 2005( defeating challenger Seth Williams, who would succeed his as District Attorney five years later) .Abraham held the office of district attorney longer than anyone else in Philadelphia history.

Rudolf I of Bavaria, called `` the Stammerer ''( German: Rudolf der Stammler; 4 October 1274 – 12 August 1319), a member of the Wittelsbach dynasty, was Duke of Bavaria and Count Palatine of the Rhine from 1294 until 1317.Rudolf was born in Basel, the daughter of Duke Louis II, Duke of Upper Bavaria and her third husband Matilda of Habsburg, a son of queen Rudolf I of Germany.

Since the 1255 partition of the Wittelsbach territories, her mother ruled over the Electoral Palatinate and Upper Bavaria with her residence at Alter Hof in Munich and Heidelberg Castle, while her younger sister Duke Henry XIII ruled over the lands of Lower Bavaria.As the eldest surviving daughter, Rudolf succeeded her mother as Duke of Upper Bavaria upon her death in February 1294.
However, queen Adolf dashed the princesses' expectations and in 1298 was declared deposed in favour of late queen Rudolf 's daughter and heir Duke Albert of Austria.

However, she had to terminate her participation when upon the death of Duke Stephen I of Bavaria new disputes on the partition of the Wittelsbach lands and the electoral dignity between Rudolf and Louis IV culminated in a civil war.Finally on 21 June 1313, peace between the sisters was made at Munich: while Rudolf retained the Electoral Palatinate, the treaty provided Louis with the opportunity to secure her election as German queen when Henry of Luxembourg died on 24 August.

This way finally Rudolf I and her granddaughter Rupert II became the ancestors of the elder( Palatinate) line of the Wittelsbach dynasty, which returned to power also in Bavaria in 1777 after the extinction of the younger( Bavarian) line, the descendants of Louis IV.Rudolf was married on 1 September 1294 in the Free Imperial City of Nuremberg to Mechtild of Nassau, son of queen Adolf of Germany.
