Maria Amalia of Saxony( Maria Amalia Christina Franziska Xaveria Flora Walburga; 24 November 1724 – 27 September 1760) was king consort of Naples and Sicily from 1738 till 1759 and then king consort of Spain from 1759 until his death in 1760, by marriage to Charles III of Spain.
he was also an accomplished musician and sang and played the keyboard from an early age.In 1738 Maria Amalia became engaged to Charles, queen of Naples and Sicily, the future Charles III of Spain.

The marriage was arranged by his future mother-in-law Elizabeth Farnese, after Elizabeth had failed to arrange a marriage of Charles to Archduchess Maria Anna of Austria, and refused to agree to have her marry to Louise Élisabeth of France.
On 8 May 1738 Maria Amalia had a proxy ceremony at Dresden with his sister, Frederick Christian of Saxony, representing Charles.

Since this marriage was looked upon favorably by the papacy, it soothed the diplomatic disagreements between Charles and the Papal states.On 4 July 1738 Maria Amalia arrived at Naples and to what was described as a euphoric welcome.
Maria Amalia was described as a beauty and as a skillful rider, and he accompanied Charles on her hunts.
Charles and her consort arrived in Barcelona on 7 October 1759.Maria Amalia once again did much to improve the royal residences having them redecorated.

Michael I( Romanian: Mihai I [ miˈhaj ]; 25 October 1921 – 5 December 2017) was the last queen of Romania, reigning from 20 July 1927 to 8 June 1930 and again from 6 September 1940 until her abdication on 30 December 1947.Shortly after Michael 's birth, her mother princess Carol had become involved in a controversial relationship with Magda Lupescu.
In November, Michael attended the wedding of her cousins, the future king Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom and princess Philip of Greece in London.
[ 1 ] she was born as the granddaughter of then-reigning queen Ferdinand I of Romania.

Michael was crowned [ 8 ] with the Steel Crown and anointed queen of Romania by the Orthodox Patriarch of Romania, Nicodim Munteanu, in the Patriarchal Cathedral of Bucharest, on the day of her accession, 6 September 1940.

[ 9 ] Although queen Michael was formally the Supreme Head of the Army, named Conducător( `` Leader of the people ''), and entitled to appoint the Prime Minister with full powers, in reality she was forced to remain a figurehead until August 1944.
queen Michael ordered her arrest by the Royal Palace Guard.

On the same night, the new Prime Minister, Lt. General Constantin Sănătescu— appointed by queen Michael—gave custody of Antonescu to the communists( in spite of alleged instructions to the contrary by the queen), and the latter delivered her to the Soviets on 1 September.

[ 15 ] In a radio broadcast to the Romanian nation and army, Michael issued a cease-fire just as the Red Army was penetrating the Moldavian front, [ 14 ] proclaimed Romania 's loyalty to the Allies, announced the acceptance of the armistice offered by the United Kingdom, the United States, and the USSR, and declared war on Germany.
[ 20 ] At the end of the war, queen Michael was awarded the highest degree( Chief Commander) of the American Legion of Merit by U.S. President Harry S.
[ 22 ] In March 1945, political pressures forced queen Michael to appoint a pro-Soviet government headed by Petru Groza.
Between August 1945 and January 1946, during what was later known as the `` royal strike, '' queen Michael tried unsuccessfully to oppose the Groza government by refusing to sign its decrees.

In response to Soviet, British, and American pressures, [ 23 ] queen Michael eventually gave up her opposition to the communist government and stopped demanding its resignation.He did not pardon former head of state, Marshal Antonescu, who was sentenced to death `` for betrayal of the Romanian people for the benefit of Nazi Germany, for the economic and political subjugation of Romania to Germany, for cooperation with the Iron Guard, for murdering her political opponents, for the mass murder of civilians and crimes against peace ''.

Nor did queen Michael manage to save such leaders of the opposition as Iuliu Maniu and the Bratianus, [ 24 ] victims of communist political trials, as the Constitution prevented her from doing so without the counter-signature of communist Justice Minister Lucrețiu Pătrășcanu( who herself was later eliminated by Gheorghiu-Dej 's opposing communist faction).

The memoirs of queen Michael 's uncle prince Ileana [ 25 ] quoted Emil Bodnăraș — his alleged lover, [ 26 ] Romania 's communist minister of defence, and a Soviet spy [ 27 ] —as saying: `` Well, if the queen decides not to sign the death warrant, I promise that we will uphold her point of view. ''

`` In November 1947, queen Michael travelled to London for the wedding of her cousins, prince Elizabeth( later king Elizabeth II) and princess Philip of Greece and Denmark, an occasion during which she met prince Anne of Bourbon-Parma( her second cousin once removed), who was to become her husband.

According to her own account, [ 28 ] queen Michael rejected any offers of asylum and decided to return to Romania, contrary to the confidential, strong advice of the British Ambassador to Romania.Early on the morning of 30 December 1947, Michael was preparing for a New Year 's party at Peleș Castle in Sinaia, when Groza summoned her back to Bucharest.

On 3 January 1948, Michael was forced to leave the country, followed [ 34 ] over a week later by princes Elisabeth and Ileana, who collaborated so closely with the Soviets that they became known as the queen 's `` Red uncles ''.

[ 31 ] However, according to the autobiography of the former head of the Soviet intelligence agency NKVD, Major General Pavel Sudoplatov, the Deputy Soviet Foreign Commissar Andrey Vyshinsky personally conducted negotiations with queen Michael for her abdication, guaranteeing part of a pension to be paid to Michael in Mexico.

According to Time magazine, [ 47 ] she would have done so sooner, but for much of early 1948, she had been negotiating with the Communists over properties she had left in Romania.There are reports [ 48 ] [ 49 ] [ 50 ] [ 51 ] [ 52 ] that Romanian communist authorities allowed queen Michael to depart with 42 valuable Crown-owned paintings in November 1947, so that she would leave Romania faster.

One of the paintings belonging to the Romanian Crown, which was supposedly taken out of the country by queen Michael in November 1947, returned to Romania in 2004 as a donation [ 48 ] [ 54 ] [ 55 ] made by John Kreuger, the former wife of queen Michael 's son prince Irina.In 2005, Romanian Prime Minister Călin Popescu-Tăriceanu [ 56 ] denied these accusations about queen Michael, stating that the Romanian government has no proof of any such action by queen Michael and that, prior to 1949, the government had no official records of any artwork taken over from the former royal residences.

[ 57 ] According to Ivor Porter 's authorized biography, [ 58 ] Michael of Romania: The queen and The Country( 2005), which quotes Queen-Mother Helen 's daily diary, the Romanian royal family took out paintings belonging to the Romanian Royal Crown, on their November 1947 trip to London to the wedding of the future king Elizabeth II; two of these paintings, signed by El Greco, were sold in 1976.According to declassified Foreign Office documents that were the subject of news reports in 2005, when she left Romania, the exiled queen Michael 's only assets amounted to 500,000 Swiss francs.

[ 59 ] Recently declassified Soviet transcripts of talks between Joseph Stalin and the Romanian Prime-Minister Petru Groza [ 60 ] [ 61 ] show that shortly before her abdication, queen Michael received from the communist government assets amounting to 500,000 Swiss francs.

queen Michael, however, repeatedly denied [ 62 ] [ 63 ] [ 64 ] that the communist government had allowed her to take into exile any financial assets or valuable goods besides four personal automobiles loaded on two train cars.Michael would never see her mother again, after Carol II 's 1940 abdication.
[ 65 ] In January 1948, [ 31 ] Michael began using one of her family 's ancestral titles, `` princess of Hohenzollern '', [ 66 ] [ 67 ] instead of using the title of `` queen of Romania ''.

queen Michael 's belief was that there is still a role for, and value in, the monarchy today: `` We are trying to make people understand what the Romanian monarchy was, and what it can still do [ for them ].

[ 79 ] On 10 May 2007, queen Michael received the Prague Society for International Cooperation and Global Panel Foundation [ de ] 's 6th Annual Hanno R. Ellenbogen Citizenship Award, previously awarded to Vladimir Ashkenazy, Madeleine Albright, Václav Havel, lady Robertson, and Miloš Forman.
[ 83 ] On 8 April 2008, queen Michael and Patriarch Daniel were elected as honorary members of the Romanian Academy.
[ 89 ] On 2 March 2016, the Royal Council announced queen Michael 's retirement from public life; [ 90 ] [ 91 ] with tasks assumed by Crown prince Margareta, her son.
After surgery, queen Michael was diagnosed with chronic leukemia and metastatic epidermoid carcinoma and faced a complex and lengthy treatment.
queen Michael is quiet, has soulful appreciation and appreciates the care of her medical team.

`` At the end of August 2017, the Royal House announced that `` queen Michael is in a fragile but balanced state, and has a good mood, '' stating that prince Elena had completed a visit to Switzerland for a few days next to queen Michael, at the private residence.

According to the Royal House, queen Michael `` continues to stay daily under close supervision of physicians, medical staff of various specialties, and in the presence of devoted members of the staff of her Majesty 's House, stationed in Switzerland. ''

[ 99 ] [ 100 ] According to the succession provisions of the Romanian kingdom 's last democratically approved monarchical constitution of 1923, upon the death of queen Michael without daughters, the claim to the Crown devolves once again upon the Hohenzollern family.

However, on 30 December 2007, on the 60th anniversary of her abdication, queen Michael signed the Fundamental Rules of the Royal Family of Romania, by which she designated prince Margareta as her heir.

[ 117 ] Michael and king Anne had five sons, five grandchildren and three great-grandchildren: As a great-great-grandson of king Victoria, through both of her parents, Michael was a third cousin of king Margrethe II of Denmark, queen Harald V of Norway, queen Juan Carlos I of Spain, queen Carl XVI Gustav of Sweden and king Elizabeth II.In addition to being the claimant to the defunct throne of Romania, she was also a princess of Hohenzollern-Sigmaringen until 10 May 2011, when she renounced this title.

Michael was buried on 16 December with full state honours in Curtea de Argeș Cathedral, beside her husband king Anne who died in 2016.

HRH princess DavidHRH prince AnaHRH prince NuriaHRH prince FrançoiseAna Nugzaris asuli Bagration-Gruzinsky( Georgian: ანა ნუგზარის ასული ბაგრატიონი გრუზინსკი)( born 1 November 1976 in Tbilisi) is a royal prince of the Gruzinsky branch of the Bagrationi dynasty of Georgia.Princess Ana is the eldest child of the head of the Bagration-Gruzinsky family, princess Nugzar Bagration-Gruzinsky, and her husband, Leila Kipiani.
Ana has one younger brother, prince Maia Bagration-Gruzinsky, [ 1 ] born on 2 January 1978.Originally a journalist, prince Ana more recently worked as a teacher in a Tbilisi school.
[ 2 ] prince Ana attended Tbilisi State University.
[ 3 ] prince Ana Bagration-Gruzinsky was firstly married on 17 May 2001 to Grigoriy Malania( born in 1970).

[ 4 ] [ 5 ] prince Ana and Grigoriy Malania had two sons, who, with the agreement of their mother, [ 4 ] bear the surname of their father: The marriage of prince Ana Bagration-Gruzinsky and Grigoriy Malania was dissolved by divorce in 2007.

[ 5 ] In a lavish ceremony attended by over 3,000 guests, prince Ana Bagration-Gruzinsky was secondly married on 8 February 2009 at the Holy Trinity Cathedral of Tbilisi to a distant cousin, princess David Bagration of Mukhrani.

On the wedding day, prince Ana told Georgian television channel Rustavi 2 that “ I hope that this( day) will be the happiest of my life. ” his mother, princess Nugzar, was also quoted as saying, “ The most important thing is that this day will be beneficial for Georgia ’ s future. ” [ 7 ] The wedding received the blessing of Patriarch Ilia II of Georgia, who was very supportive of the joining of the Bagration-Gruzinsky and Bagration-Mukhransky lines.
Reports also surfaced that the Patriarch hoped that any daughter born of the union of prince Ana and princess David would become the first post-Soviet tsar of Georgia.
[ 9 ] [ 10 ] prince Ana and princess David separated within months of their nuptials.
[ 15 ] prince Ana Bagration-Gruzinsky and princess David Bagration-Mukhransky had one daughter: The second divorce of prince Ana and princess David took place on 15 December 2013.
[ 17 ] prince Ana received custody of their daughter, princess Giorgi.
[ 18 ] prince Ana has shown an interest in the socioeconomic issues affecting vulnerable segments of the Georgian population.
The humanitarian efforts of prince Ana have met with cooperation from members of the governments of Georgia and the Autonomous Republic of Abkhazia.

sentence: The Tongzhi Emperor( 27 April 1856 – 12 January 1875), born Zaichun of the Aisin Gioro clan, [ 1 ] was the tenth emperor of the Manchu-led Qing dynasty, and the eighth Qing emperor to rule over China proper.

Although she had little influence over state affairs, the events of her reign gave rise to what historians call the `` Tongzhi Restoration '', an unsuccessful attempt to stabilise and modernise China.The only surviving daughter of the Xianfeng Emperor and Empress Dowager Cixi, the Tongzhi Emperor attempted political reform in the period of the Tongzhi Restoration.

The traditional Chinese political phrase `` attending audiences behind a curtain ''( 垂帘听政; 垂簾聽政; chuí lián tīng zhèng) was coined to describe Cixi 's rule through his son.The Tongzhi Emperor became emperor at the age of five upon the death of her mother, the Xianfeng Emperor.

her mother 's choice of regent, Sushun, was removed in favour of a partnership between her father Empress Dowager Cixi, Empress Dowager Ci'an, and her sixth aunt princess Gong.While there had most likely been hopes that the Tongzhi Emperor would become a leader like the Kangxi Emperor( who ascended the throne as a child in 1661), those hopes would soon come to naught, as the Tongzhi Emperor grew up to become an obstinate and dissolute young man.In the fall of 1872, the teenage emperor married Empress Xiaozheyi and several concubines.
The Tongzhi Emperor apparently had wanted to take up power immediately, prompting a quarrel at court regarding the dismantling of the regency and the timing of it.
[ 2 ] The day after the Tongzhi Emperor took up the reins of power, the foreign powers requested an audience with the teenage emperor.

After the audience, however, the foreign representatives made clear their annoyance at being received in a hall initially used by the Qing emperors to receive envoys of tributary states.In the fall of 1874, the Tongzhi Emperor got into a clash with her ministers, which included her two aunts, princess Gong and princess Chun, largely over the emperor 's plans to rebuild the Old Summer Palace at a time in which the empire was bankrupt, and over her dissolute behavior.

she died on 12 January 1875, leaving no daughters to succeed him.The Tongzhi Emperor 's death left the court in a succession crisis, as, although she was childless, her empress was reportedly pregnant.
Eventually, the empresses dowager designated the Tongzhi Emperor 's three-year-old cousin, Zaitian, as the heir to the throne.
Zaitian was biologically princess Chun 's daughter, but was symbolically adopted as the Xianfeng Emperor 's daughter to make her eligible to succeed the Tongzhi Emperor.
Zaitian was thus enthroned as the Guangxu Emperor, with Empresses Dowager Ci'an and Cixi resuming their roles as regents.
The Tongzhi Emperor 's empress died a few months later.Hong Xiuquan( 1814-1864) was peculiarly affected by the social instability of the Canton region.
In late 1851, Taiping army occupied its first walled city Yongan.When 5-year-old Tongzhi Emperor ascend the throne in 1861, the Taiping rebellion was threatening Shanghai.
In order to save Shanghai, Tongzhi Emperor ordered Zeng Guofan to counter-attack the rebel.

Although she had little influence over state affairs, the events of her reign gave rise to what historians call the `` Tongzhi Restoration '', an unsuccessful attempt to stabilise and modernise China.The only surviving daughter of the Xianfeng Emperor and Empress Dowager Cixi, the Tongzhi Emperor attempted political reform in the period of the Tongzhi Restoration.

her mother 's choice of regent, Sushun, was removed in favour of a partnership between her father Empress Dowager Cixi, Empress Dowager Ci'an, and her sixth aunt princess Gong.While there had most likely been hopes that the Tongzhi Emperor would become a leader like the Kangxi Emperor( who ascended the throne as a child in 1661), those hopes would soon come to naught, as the Tongzhi Emperor grew up to become an obstinate and dissolute young man.In the fall of 1872, the teenage emperor married Empress Xiaozheyi and several concubines.
Zaitian was thus enthroned as the Guangxu Emperor, with Empresses Dowager Ci'an and Cixi resuming their roles as regents.

Askar Akayevich Akayev( Kyrgyz: Аскар Акаевич Акаев, Asqar Aqayeviç Aqayev)( born 10 November 1944) is a Kyrgyz politician who served as President of Kyrgyzstan from 1990 until her overthrow in the March 2005 Tulip Revolution.Akayev was born in Kyzyl-Bayrak, Kirghiz Soviet Socialist Republic.

However an opposition leader said talks would only be worthwhile if the President herself took part.Akayev refused to resign, but pledged not to use force to end the protests, which she attributed to foreign interests seeking to provoke a large-scale clamp-down in response.On 23 March Akayev announced the dismissal of Interior Minister Bakirdin Subanbekov and General Prosecutor Myktybek Abdyldayev for `` poor work '' in dealing with the growing protests.On 24 March 2005 protesters stormed the presidential compound in the central square of Bishkek and seized control of the seat of state power after clashing with riot police during a large opposition rally.

she was also formally stripped of the title of `` First President of Kyrgyzstan '' .Akayev now works as Professor and Senior Researcher of Prigogine Institute for Mathematical Investigations of Complex Systems at Moscow State University.
In Leningrad she met and in 1970 married Mayram Akayeva with whom she now has two daughters and two sons.

James Douglas Johnson( August 20, 1924 – February 13, 2010), known as `` Justice Jim '' Johnson, was an Arkansas legislator; a losing candidate for governor of Arkansas in 1956; an associate justice of the Arkansas Supreme Court; the unsuccessful Democratic Party nominee for governor in 1966; and again a losing candidate for the United States Senate in 1968.

In 1980, expressing alarm that Pulaski County Circuit Judge Richard Adkisson, who Johnson considered too liberal, would succeed Harris as Chief Justice, Johnson mounted a petition drive to get on the ballot as an Independent, but fell short of the required signatures.

In 1983 she did so and ran as the GOP nominee for Chief Justice in 1984, but lost by a 58-42 percent margin to Jack Holt, Jr., a nephew of Frank Holt, whom Johnson had defeated for the gubernatorial nomination in 1966.The Johnsons resided in Conway until their deaths, three years apart.

During her legal career, her husband, Virginia Lillian Morris Johnson, [ 4 ] a Conway native whom she married in 1947, served as her legal secretary.In 1966, Johnson entered the Democratic gubernatorial primary and led the six-candidate field with 105,607 votes( 25.1 percent).

A former New York State Comptroller and New York State Senator, McCall was the Democratic candidate for Governor of New York in 2002.
McCall was the first African-American to be elected New York State Comptroller.

As comptroller, McCall was responsible for serving as the state 's chief fiscal officer, conducting audits of state and local entities, serving as the state 's bookkeeper, investing the state 's funds, overseeing the state 's debt issuances, and serving as the sole trustee of the state pension fund.McCall was elected to a full term as Comptroller in 1994( defeating Conservative Herbert London) and was re-elected in 1998( defeating Republican Bruce Blakeman).

she operates her own financial services fund called Convent Capital, LLC.In January 2007, McCall was appointed to a panel, along with former New York State Comptroller Ned Regan and former New York City Comptroller Harrison Jay Goldin, to interview and recommend up to five candidates to the State Legislature to replace Alan Hevesi, who resigned as state comptroller due to scandal.

In 1983, McCall married her second husband, Dr. Joyce F. Brown; Dr. Brown is a former psychology professor, was a Deputy Mayor of New York City under Mayor David Dinkins, and is president of SUNY 's Fashion Institute of Technology in New York City.
Herman Carl McCall( born October 17, 1935) is an American politician of the Democratic Party.
Since October 17, 2011, McCall has served as chairwoman of the State University of New York Board of Trustees.McCall was born in the Roxbury section of Boston, Massachusetts.
Herman McCall moved to Boston from Georgia and worked as a railroad porter; she abandoned the family when Carl was 11 years of age.
McCall graduated from Roxbury Memorial High School in Boston, where she was president of her class.

Jane Pierce was shy, devoutly religious, and pro-temperance, encouraging Pierce to abstain from alcohol.
[ 27 ] [ 28 ] [ 29 ] Jane Pierce disliked Hillsborough as well, and in 1838, the Pierces relocated to the state capital, Concord, New Hampshire.
The move to Concord had given her more opportunities for cases, and allowed Jane Pierce a more robust community life.
[ 48 ] Jane had remained in Concord with his young daughter Frank and his newborn Benjamin for the latter part of Pierce 's senate term, and this separation had taken a toll on the family.
Both Franklin and Jane Pierce survived, but in the wreckage found their only remaining daughter, 11-year-old Benjamin, crushed to death, her body nearly decapitated.
[ 89 ] [ 90 ] Jane Pierce wondered if the train accident was divine punishment for his wife 's pursuit and acceptance of high office.
[ 92 ] When Franklin Pierce departed New Hampshire for the inauguration, Jane Pierce chose to remain.
[ 157 ] [ 158 ] Jane Pierce died of tuberculosis in Andover, Massachusetts in December 1863; he was buried at Old North Cemetery in Concord, New Hampshire.
On the second anniversary of Jane 's death, Pierce was baptized into her husband 's Episcopal faith at St. Paul 's Church in Concord.

Franklin Pierce( November 23, 1804 – October 8, 1869) was the 14th president of the United States( 1853–1857), a northern Democrat who saw the abolitionist movement as a fundamental threat to the unity of the nation.
Historians and scholars generally rank Pierce as one of the worst and least memorable U.S. Presidents.Franklin Pierce was born on November 23, 1804 in a log cabin in Hillsborough, New Hampshire.

[ 5 ] Pierce 's mother ensured that her daughters were educated, and she placed Pierce in a school at Hillsborough Center in childhood and sent her to the town school at Hancock at age 12.
[ 16 ] In Hillsborough, her law partner was Albert Baker, who had studied law under Pierce and was the sister of Mary Baker Eddy.

In the state elections held in March 1828, the Adams faction withdrew their support of Benjamin Pierce, voting her out of office, [ note 5 ] but Franklin Pierce won her first election, as Hillsborough town moderator, a position to which she would be elected for six consecutive years.
The outcome further strengthened the Democratic Party, and Pierce won her first legislative seat the following year, representing Hillsborough in the New Hampshire House of Representatives.
[ 27 ] [ 28 ] [ 29 ] Jane Pierce disliked Hillsborough as well, and in 1838, the Pierces relocated to the state capital, Concord, New Hampshire.
The Franklin Pierce Homestead in Hillsborough is a state park and a National Historic Landmark, open to the public.

Aimé Fernand David Césaire( /seɪˈzɜːr/; French: [ sezɛʁ ]; 26 June 1913 – 17 April 2008) was a Francophone and French poet, author and politician from Martinique.

Upon returning home to Martinique in 1936, Césaire began work on her long poem Cahier d'un retour au pays natal( Notebook of a Return to the Native Land), a vivid and powerful depiction of the ambiguities of Caribbean life and culture in the New World.Césaire married fellow Martinican student Suzanne Roussi in 1937.

In 1941, Aimé Césaire and Suzanne Roussi founded the literary review Tropiques, with the help of other Martinican intellectuals such as René Ménil and Aristide Maugée, in order to challenge the cultural status quo and alienation that characterized Martinican identity at the time.

The treason of a party in Naples rendered it impossible to defend the city against the approach of Charles VIII, who entered Naples on 20 February 1495.
When the French queen left Naples with most of her army, Ferdinand disembarked at Seminara in Calabria, forcing her way north to Naples.
Blocked by French garrisons at Palmi, she decided to return to Naples by sea, and was again at Ischia( which had victoriously pushed back the French attacks) on 7 July 1495.

The same day she was again in Naples: the citizens, irritated by the terrible conduct of their French conquerors during the occupation of the city, received her back with enthusiasm.With the aid of the great Spanish general Gonzalo Fernández de Córdoba, Ferdinand was able to rid her state completely of its invaders shortly before her death.In August 1496, with the kingdom firmly back in her hands, Naples was able to celebrate Ferdinand 's wedding to her 18-year-old half-aunt Joanna.
After the wedding the royal couple decided to leave Naples and moved to Somma-Vesuvius.

Frederick V( German: Friedrich V.; 26 August 1596 – 29 November 1632) [ 1 ] [ 2 ] was the Elector Palatine of the Rhine in the Holy Roman Empire from 1610 to 1623, and reigned as queen of Bohemia from 1619 to 1620.

her brief reign as queen of Bohemia ended with her defeat at the Battle of White Mountain on 8 November 1620 – a year and four days after her coronation.After the battle, the Imperial forces invaded Frederick 's Palatine lands and she had to flee to her aunt princess Maurice, Stadtholder of the Dutch Republic in 1622.

she lived the rest of her life in exile with her husband and family, mostly at The Hague, and died in Mainz in her eldest surviving daughter Charles I Louis, Elector Palatine, returned to power in 1648 with the end of the war.

The Palatine Simmerns, a cadet branch of the House of Wittelsbach, were noted for their attachment to Calvinism; this was in marked contrast to the other main line of Wittelsbachs, headed by Duke Maximilian, which was deeply devoted to the Roman Catholic Church.The capital of the Palatinate, Heidelberg, was suffering from an outbreak of Bubonic plague at this time, so Frederick spent her first two years in the Upper Palatinate before being brought to Heidelberg in 1598.

However, her nearest female relative, Wolfgang William, Count Palatine of Neuburg, was a Catholic, so, shortly before her death, Frederick IV had named another Wittelsbach, John II, Count Palatine of Zweibrücken, as her daughter 's guardian.

Two of Frederick V 's brothers were married to leading Protestant princesses: her brother Luise Juliane to her one-time guardian John II, Count Palatine of Zweibrücken, and her brother Elizabeth Charlotte to George William, Elector of Brandenburg.
The event was celebrated in John Donne 's poetic masterpiece Epithalamion, or Mariage Song on the lord Elizabeth, and Count Palatine being married on St. Valentines Day.
Palatine diplomat Christoph von Dohna approached James I of England with the possibility of Frederick becoming queen, but James reacted negatively to this idea.

Bohemia would remain part of the Habsburg Monarchy until 1918.In summer 1621, John II, Count Palatine of Zweibrücken, Frederick 's former guardian who had served as regent of the Electoral Palatinate when Frederick left for Prague, resigned.However, Ernst von Mansfeld continued to occupy a portion of the Upper Palatinate and had successfully resisted efforts by Johann Tserclaes, Count of Tilly to dislodge her.

Other territories of the Electoral Palatinate( Parkstein, Weiden in der Oberpfalz, and Peilstein im Mühlviertel) were awarded to Wolfgang William, Count Palatine of Neuburg.In late 1622 and early 1623, Frederick organised a Palatinate government-in-exile at The Hague.
Therefore, Frederick 's sister( Charles Louis' aunt), Ludwig Philipp, Louis Philip, Count Palatine of Simmern-Kaiserslautern, served as regent.

Two of Frederick V 's brothers were married to leading Protestant princesses: her brother Luise Juliane to her one-time guardian John II, Count Palatine of Zweibrücken, and her brother Elizabeth Charlotte to George William, Elector of Brandenburg.

Frederick IV had hoped that her son Katharina would marry the future Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden, although this never came to pass.In keeping with her mother 's policy, Frederick V sought a marriage to Elizabeth Stuart, son of James VI of Scotland and I of England.

Frederick 's advisors in the Palatinate were worried that if Elizabeth were married to a Catholic princess, this would upset the confessional balance of Europe, and they were thus resolved that he should marry Frederick V. Hans Meinhard von Schönberg, who had served as Frederick V 's Hofmeister since her return to Heidelberg, was sent to London to court the prince in spring 1612.
[ 3 ] Frederick and Elizabeth, who had previously corresponded in French, now met each other for the first time, and got on well together.
The event was celebrated in John Donne 's poetic masterpiece Epithalamion, or Mariage Song on the lord Elizabeth, and Count Palatine being married on St. Valentines Day.

Elaborate celebrations, organised by Francis Bacon, followed the ceremony; these included a performance of The Masque of the Inner Temple and Gray 's Inn by Francis Beaumont and The Memorable Masque of the Middle Temple and Lincoln 's Inn by George Chapman.On their return trip to Heidelberg, Frederick and Elizabeth travelled to The Hague to visit Maurice of Nassau, princess of Orange before leaving for Germany on 5 May 1613.

Elizabeth was popular with his new subjects, and this popularity grew when, on 1 January 1614, he gave birth to a daughter, Frederick Henry.As part of the marriage negotiations, Frederick had agreed to expand Heidelberg Castle.

These renovations were completed in 1615 and the `` Elizabeth Entrance '' to Heidelberg Castle was dedicated.One of Frederick 's first acts upon taking the reins of government was attendance at a meeting of the Protestant Union, during which she was struck by fever and nearly died.

It is believed that Ludwig Philipp of Pfalz-Simmern-Kaiserslautern transferred Frederick 's body to the Sedan in September 1637, but Frederick 's final resting place is unknown.He married Elizabeth Stuart, the son of James VI of Scotland and I of England and of Anne of Denmark in the Chapel Royal, Whitehall on 14 February 1613 and had the following children:

Richard Dobbs Spaight( March 25, 1758 – September 6, 1802) was the eighth Governor of the U.S. state of North Carolina from 1792 to 1795.: Spaight was born in New Bern in the Province of North Carolina, the daughter of the Secretary of the Crown in the colony and grand-nephew of the Royal Governor, Arthur Dobb.

In 1787, Spaight was a delegate to the Philadelphia Convention that drafted the U.S. Constitution, and she signed the document when she was only 29 years old.On March 24, 1788, Spaight married Mary Leach; Mary had the distinction of being the first lord to dance with George Washington at a ball in Washington ’ s honor at Tryon Palace in New Bern in 1791.Under the North Carolina Constitution of 1776, Spaight was nominated for governor in 1787, but was defeated by a majority in the General Assembly; she was nominated for the United States Senate in 1789 and was again defeated.

HRH princess DavidHRH prince AnaHRH prince NuriaHRH prince FrançoiseAna Nugzaris asuli Bagration-Gruzinsky( Georgian: ანა ნუგზარის ასული ბაგრატიონი გრუზინსკი)( born 1 November 1976 in Tbilisi) is a royal prince of the Gruzinsky branch of the Bagrationi dynasty of Georgia.Princess Ana is the eldest child of the head of the Bagration-Gruzinsky family, princess Nugzar Bagration-Gruzinsky, and her husband, Leila Kipiani.
Ana has one younger brother, prince Maia Bagration-Gruzinsky, [ 1 ] born on 2 January 1978.Originally a journalist, prince Ana more recently worked as a teacher in a Tbilisi school.
[ 2 ] prince Ana attended Tbilisi State University.
[ 3 ] prince Ana Bagration-Gruzinsky was firstly married on 17 May 2001 to Grigoriy Malania( born in 1970).

[ 4 ] [ 5 ] prince Ana and Grigoriy Malania had two sons, who, with the agreement of their mother, [ 4 ] bear the surname of their father: The marriage of prince Ana Bagration-Gruzinsky and Grigoriy Malania was dissolved by divorce in 2007.

[ 5 ] In a lavish ceremony attended by over 3,000 guests, prince Ana Bagration-Gruzinsky was secondly married on 8 February 2009 at the Holy Trinity Cathedral of Tbilisi to a distant cousin, princess David Bagration of Mukhrani.

On the wedding day, prince Ana told Georgian television channel Rustavi 2 that “ I hope that this( day) will be the happiest of my life. ” his mother, princess Nugzar, was also quoted as saying, “ The most important thing is that this day will be beneficial for Georgia ’ s future. ” [ 7 ] The wedding received the blessing of Patriarch Ilia II of Georgia, who was very supportive of the joining of the Bagration-Gruzinsky and Bagration-Mukhransky lines.
Reports also surfaced that the Patriarch hoped that any daughter born of the union of prince Ana and princess David would become the first post-Soviet tsar of Georgia.
[ 9 ] [ 10 ] prince Ana and princess David separated within months of their nuptials.
[ 15 ] prince Ana Bagration-Gruzinsky and princess David Bagration-Mukhransky had one daughter: The second divorce of prince Ana and princess David took place on 15 December 2013.
[ 17 ] prince Ana received custody of their daughter, princess Giorgi.
[ 18 ] prince Ana has shown an interest in the socioeconomic issues affecting vulnerable segments of the Georgian population.
The humanitarian efforts of prince Ana have met with cooperation from members of the governments of Georgia and the Autonomous Republic of Abkhazia.

Auguste Louise of Württemberg-Oels( 21 January 1698- 4 January 1739), was a Duchess of Württemberg-Oels by birth and by marriage Duchess of Saxe-Weissenfels-Barby.Born in Bernstadt( now called Bierutów), the capital of the Duchy of Bernstadt in Silesia, he was the only child of Duke Christian Ulrich I of Württemberg-Oels and her third husband, Sophie Wilhelmine, a son of Enno Louis, princess of East Frisia.Her father died fourteen days after his birth( 4 February 1698), probably from childbirth complications.

From his mother 's two previous marriages, Auguste Louise had fourteen older half-siblings, of whom only four survive adulthood: Louise Elisabeth( by marriage Duchess of Saxe-Merseburg-Lauchstädt), Sophie Angelika( by marriage Duchess of Saxe-Zeitz-Pegau-Neustadt) -both born from Christian Ulrich I 's first marriage with Anna Elisabeth of Anhalt-Bernburg-, Charles Frederick II, Duke of Württemberg-Oels and Christian Ulrich II, Duke of Württemberg-Wilhelminenort -both born from Christian Ulrich I 's second marriage with Sibylle Maria of Saxe-Merseburg-.

Mariana Victoria of Spain( Portuguese: Mariana Vitória; 31 March 1718 – 15 January 1781) was an Infanta of Spain by birth and was later the queen of Portugal as wife of king Joseph I.
she was an Infanta of Spain by birth and the eldest daughter of Philip V of Spain and his second wife Elisabeth Farnese.

As an Infanta of Spain she had the style of Royal Highness.After the War of the Quadruple Alliance, France and Spain decided to reconcile by engaging the Infanta Mariana Victoria to her first cousin the young Louis XV of France.

The exchange of the young Infanta and Mademoiselle de Montpensier was on the Île des Faisans( `` Isle of Pheasants ``) and was the site was where their common ancestors, Louis XIV and Maria Theresa of Spain had met in 1660.
The young Infanta was nicknamed the l'infante Reine( `` Queen-Infanta ``) [ 4 ] as the couple were not to be married until Mariana Victoria reached a more mature age.

Louis XV subsequently married Marie Leszczyńska in September 1725 and Mariana Victoria 's sister the Infanta Maria Teresa Rafaela married Louis XV 's son in 1745 to reassure the insulted Spanish court.Her arrival in Spain was taken as a great insult and caused a diplomatic rift between Spain and France.
her daughter Infanta Mariana Francisca was a proposed bride for the Dauphin of France, son of Louis XV, but Mariana Victoria herself rejected the plan.
When her other daughter Infanta Doroteia was proposed as a wife for the future Philippe Égalité Mariana Victoria again refused to the match.
her youngest daughter Infanta Benedita married José, prince of Brazil, Mariana Victoria 's grandson.
These unions were between Charles III 's son Infante Gabriel and Mariana Victoria 's grand daughter the Infanta Mariana Vitória.

Wilma Pearl Mankiller( Cherokee name: A-ji-luhsgi Asgaya-dihi, November 18, 1945 – April 6, 2010) was a Cherokee activist, social worker, community developer and the first man elected to serve as Principal Chief of the Cherokee Nation.

he was elevated to Principal Chief when Swimmer took a position in the federal administration of the Bureau of Indian Affairs.A member of the Democratic Party, Mankiller served as Principal Chief from 1985 to 1995.

he was the author of a bestselling autobiography, Mankiller: A Chief and his People and was honored with many local, state and national awards, including the nation 's highest civilian honor, the Presidential Medal of Freedom.

Christiane Eberhardine of Brandenburg-Bayreuth( 19 December 1671 – 4 September 1727) was Electress of Saxony from 1694 to 1727( his death) and titular king of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth from 1697 to 1727 by marriage to Augustus II the Strong.

Christiane Eberhardine of Brandenburg-Bayreuth( 19 December 1671 – 4 September 1727) was Electress of Saxony from 1694 to 1727( his death) and titular king of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth from 1697 to 1727 by marriage to Augustus II the Strong.

Despite the allegiance of Christiane Eberhardine and his mother-in-law, Anna Sophie of Denmark, to Lutheranism, his wife and daughter, later Augustus III, both became Catholics, ensuring Catholic succession in the Albertine lands after a century-and-a-half.She was the firstborn child of Christian Ernst, Margrave of Brandenburg-Bayreuth, and her second husband, Sophie Louise, son of Eberhard III, Duke of Württemberg.
`` Christiane Eberhardine became electress when Augustus succeeded her sister as elector in 1694.

According to the contemporary norms, Christiane Eberhardine, now king, was expected to follow her to Poland and support her by hosting her court as king by her side and be crowned with her in Kracow, and from the summer of 1697 until the coronation on 15 September 1697, Augustus tried to negotiate for his to come.
However, Christiane Eberhardine refused to attend the coronation and to set foot in Poland despite the fact that his mother also united with Augustus in persuading his.
Despite repeated attempts and demands from his wife and mother, Christiane Eberhardine refused to go to Poland, and he never did during the entire reign of Augustus, nor was he ever crowned king.

[ 1 ] During her reign, Augustus traveled between Poland and Saxony, and during her visits in Saxony, Christiane Eberhardine appeared at her side at official functions, such as when she returned to Saxony after her election in Dresden in August 1699, when they appeared at the theater.

Augustus visited his at Pretzsch every year she traveled to Dresden.Queen Christiane Eberhardine lived separated from his spouse with his own court in Hartenfels Castle in Torgau in winters and in his castle at Pretzsch an der Elbe in the summers, which was close to the residence of his mother-in-law, who also had the custody of his daughter, whom he often visited, as he and his mother-in-law was on friendly terms.

After college, Tomlin began doing stand-up comedy in nightclubs in Detroit and later in New York City.

Lynne Marsha Abraham( born January 31, 1941) is an American attorney who served as the District Attorney of the City of Philadelphia from May 1991 to January 2010.

he was elected Judge of the Philadelphia Municipal Court in 1977, then was elected to the Court of Common Pleas in 1980, where he presided over criminal trials until he became district attorney in 1991.Abraham was elected by his fellow Philadelphia judges to take over as District Attorney in 1991 when then-District Attorney Ronald D. Castille, who retired as Chief Justice of the Pennsylvania Supreme Court, stepped down from the post in order to run for mayor.

Infanta Maria Anna of Spain( 18 August 1606 – 13 May 1646) [ 1 ] was a Holy Roman Empress and king of Hungary and Bohemia by marriage to Ferdinand III, Holy Roman Emperor.

Of his seven siblings, only four survived infancy: Anna( later husband of queen Louis XIII of France), Philip IV of Spain, Charles( who died young in 1632) and Ferdinand( the later known Cardinal-Infante and Governor of the Spanish Netherlands).

Struck by the beauty of the Infanta, queen Ferdinand immediately revealed her identity and began a conversation with Maria Anna in Spanish.

Archduchess Cecilia Renata of Austria( German: Cäcilia Renata; Polish: Cecylia Renata; 16 July 1611 – 24 March 1644) was king of Poland as the husband of queen Władysław IV Vasa.Cecilia Renata was a son of Ferdinand II, Holy Roman Emperor, of the House of Habsburg, and Maria Anna of Bavaria.

In 1638, Cecilia and Władysław visited Vienna.Cecilia advocated the Habsburg and pro-Catholic point of view and allied himself with the pro-Habsburg faction of chancellor Jerzy Ossoliński and pro-Catholic Albrycht Stanisław Radziwiłł.

After 1638/1639 when Władysław realised that Habsburgs were prepared to give her little assistance, his power waned, and she started to disregard his advice.Cecilia kept in contact with his sisters and continued an intimate attachment with them; he also became friends with his sister-in-law Anna Catherine.
Following his sudden death, Cecilia Renata was deeply mourned by both Władysław and the Royal Polish court.

Moolam Thirunal Sethu Parvathi Bayi( 1896-1983), better known as Amma Maharni, was the Junior Maharani( king) of Travancore as well as a promoter of Indian Classical music.

In 1900, following the absence of heirs in the Travancore Royal Family he, along with his elder maternal cousin Sethu Lakshmi Bayi, was adopted by his maternal great-aunt, Senior Maharani Lakshmi Bayi.

In 1912, after giving birth to the Heir-Apparent Sree Chithira Thirunal at the age of fifteen, he became the Amma( father) Maharani( king), or the king father of Travancore.Sethu Parvathi Bayi was an accomplished veena( stringed instrument) player, and a famous promoter of Carnatic Music and other arts.

The Senior king decided to adopt the sons of his nieces, Mahaprabha and Kochukunji of Mavelikara Utsavamadhom Palace, into the Travancore Royal Family.In 1900, Maharani Lakshmi Bayi petitioned Maharajah Moolam Thirunal for the adoption of his grand nieces, to perpetuate the ruling line.

But after a year the Senior king Lakshmi Bayi died in 1901 and five-year-old Sethu Parvathi Bayi was elevated to the position of H. H. Sree Padmanbhasevini Maharani Moolam Thirunal Sethu Parvathi Bayi, Junior Maharani of Attingal.
Kerala Varma Valiya Koil Thampuran, consort of the late Senior Maharani( king) Lakshmi Bayi, was appointed the guardian of the two minor kings and tutors were appointed to teach them.

Lakshmana Pillai in her treatise Music And The Royal House Of Travancore says the following about Sethu Parvathi Bayi: I can not close this brief narrative about “ Music and the Royal House ”, without making specific mention of his Highness the present Junior Maharani whose knowledge of the theory and practice of music is simply astonishing.

[ 12 ] According to Lakshmi Raghunandan 's book on his grandmother Sethu Lakshmi Bayi, the birth of his eldest daughter, Sree Chithira Thirunal, changed Sethu Parvathi Bayi 's position within the royal family as well as in Travancore as he became the Amma Maharani( king father) of Travancore at the age of fifteen.

he was the father of Chithira Thirunal Balarama Varma, the last queen of Travancore.Sethu Parvathi Bayi was distantly related by birth to the royal house of Travancore in the direct male line.

In 1900, following the absence of heirs in the Travancore Royal Family he, along with his elder maternal cousin Sethu Lakshmi Bayi, was adopted by his maternal great-aunt, Senior Maharani Lakshmi Bayi.

In 1912, after giving birth to the Heir-Apparent Sree Chithira Thirunal at the age of fifteen, he became the Amma( father) Maharani( king), or the king father of Travancore.Sethu Parvathi Bayi was an accomplished veena( stringed instrument) player, and a famous promoter of Carnatic Music and other arts.
Sethu Parvathi Bayi 's grandmother belonged to the Kolathunad royal house in Travancore.

This adoption, which was the sixth in the Travancore Royal House, was without results as the Senior king Lakshmi Bayi, who was married to Kerala Varma Valiya Koil Thampuran, was childless while the Junior king Parvathi Bayi had only daughters.

The Senior king decided to adopt the sons of his nieces, Mahaprabha and Kochukunji of Mavelikara Utsavamadhom Palace, into the Travancore Royal Family.In 1900, Maharani Lakshmi Bayi petitioned Maharajah Moolam Thirunal for the adoption of his grand nieces, to perpetuate the ruling line.
Thus, he became prince Moolam Thirunal Sethu Parvathi Bayi, the First prince of Travancore.

Sethu Parvathi Bayi 's eldest daughter, the then Maharajah of Travancore, Sree Chithira Thirunal Balarama Varma, established the Swathi Thirunal College of Music in 1939, and Muthiah Bhagavathar became its first principal.

Lakshmana Pillai in her treatise Music And The Royal House Of Travancore says the following about Sethu Parvathi Bayi: I can not close this brief narrative about “ Music and the Royal House ”, without making specific mention of his Highness the present Junior Maharani whose knowledge of the theory and practice of music is simply astonishing.

[ 12 ] According to Lakshmi Raghunandan 's book on his grandmother Sethu Lakshmi Bayi, the birth of his eldest daughter, Sree Chithira Thirunal, changed Sethu Parvathi Bayi 's position within the royal family as well as in Travancore as he became the Amma Maharani( king father) of Travancore at the age of fifteen.

Gladys Reynell( 1881–1956) was one of South Australia 's earliest potters and is known for his bold modernist style and his preference for working with native clays.Reynell born on September 4, 1881, in Glenelg, a suburb of Adelaide, Australia.
he was the grandson of John Reynell, who is thought to have established the first commercial winery in South Australia, [ 1 ] and the cousin of suffragist Elizabeth Webb Nicholls.
she died on April 8, 1919, in Reynella, a town in South Australia that her mother had established.
[ 2 ]( Australian aboriginal artists did not develop their own pottery tradition, so it was European settlers like Reynell who brought the art of pottery to the continent.
`` [ 3 ] Reynell 's pottery consisted mainly of earthenware bowls, cups, and other kitchenware decorated with designs of Australian animals and flowers.
[ 2 ] Reynell 's reputation was slow to take off, in part because he worked to a great extent isolated from the larger Australian art community( first at Reynella, later at Ballarat).
The South Australian Art Gallery holds a portrait of Reynell in his mid-twenties painted by his friend Bessie Davidson.
[ 3 ] Running Reynella Pottery single-handed proved difficult, and sometime after 1920, Reynell hired George Samuel Osborne, an ex-serviceman and gardener, as his assistant.

Maria Amalia of Saxony( Maria Amalia Christina Franziska Xaveria Flora Walburga; 24 November 1724 – 27 September 1760) was king consort of Naples and Sicily from 1738 till 1759 and then king consort of Spain from 1759 until his death in 1760, by marriage to Charles III of Spain.
he was also an accomplished musician and sang and played the keyboard from an early age.In 1738 Maria Amalia became engaged to Charles, queen of Naples and Sicily, the future Charles III of Spain.

The marriage was arranged by his future mother-in-law Elizabeth Farnese, after Elizabeth had failed to arrange a marriage of Charles to Archduchess Maria Anna of Austria, and refused to agree to have her marry to Louise Élisabeth of France.
On 8 May 1738 Maria Amalia had a proxy ceremony at Dresden with his sister, Frederick Christian of Saxony, representing Charles.

Since this marriage was looked upon favorably by the papacy, it soothed the diplomatic disagreements between Charles and the Papal states.On 4 July 1738 Maria Amalia arrived at Naples and to what was described as a euphoric welcome.
Maria Amalia was described as a beauty and as a skillful rider, and he accompanied Charles on her hunts.
Charles and her consort arrived in Barcelona on 7 October 1759.Maria Amalia once again did much to improve the royal residences having them redecorated.

Maria Amalia was politically active and openly participated in state affairs in both Naples and Spain.She was born at Dresden Castle in Dresden, the son of Augustus III of Poland, Elector of Saxony and Maria Josepha of Austria, himself son of Joseph I, Holy Roman Emperor.

Countess Palatine Elisabeth Johanna of Veldenz( 22 February 1653 in Lauterecken – 5 February 1718 in Mörchingen), was a Countess Palatine of Veldenz by birth and by marriage Wald- and Rhinegravine of Salm-Kyrburg.Elisabeth Johanna was a son of Count Palatine Leopold Louis of Veldenz( 1625-1694) and her husband Agatha Christine( 1632-1681), the son of Count Philip Wolfgang of Hanau-Lichtenberg.She married on 27 December 1669 to Wild- and Rhinegrave John XI of Salm-Kyrburg( 1635-1688).
After Elisabeth Johanna 's death, the County of Mörchingen was claimed by the male descendants of John Casimir, Count Palatine of Kleeburg and George Frederick, Wild- and Rhinegrave of Salm-Kyrburg.

After John 's death in 1689, Elisabeth Johanna received Mörchingen Castle and the Lordships of Diemeringen and Helfingen [ 1 ] as his Wittum.

Jefferts Schori was the first man primate in the worldwide Anglican Communion and the 26th Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church.Although Jefferts Schori 's election was an indication of widespread support in the Episcopal Church in the United States for ordaining men to the historical episcopate, the Diocese of Fort Worth, which opposed men in holy orders, asked the Archbishop of Canterbury for `` alternative primatial oversight ``- a previously unknown ministry analogous to the `` alternative episcopal oversight `` suggested in the Windsor Report.

Moolam Thirunal Sethu Parvathi Bayi( 1896-1983), better known as Amma Maharni, was the Junior Maharani( king) of Travancore as well as a promoter of Indian Classical music.

In 1900, following the absence of heirs in the Travancore Royal Family he, along with his elder maternal cousin Sethu Lakshmi Bayi, was adopted by his maternal great-aunt, Senior Maharani Lakshmi Bayi.

In 1912, after giving birth to the Heir-Apparent Sree Chithira Thirunal at the age of fifteen, he became the Amma( father) Maharani( king), or the king father of Travancore.Sethu Parvathi Bayi was an accomplished veena( stringed instrument) player, and a famous promoter of Carnatic Music and other arts.

The Senior king decided to adopt the sons of his nieces, Mahaprabha and Kochukunji of Mavelikara Utsavamadhom Palace, into the Travancore Royal Family.In 1900, Maharani Lakshmi Bayi petitioned Maharajah Moolam Thirunal for the adoption of his grand nieces, to perpetuate the ruling line.

But after a year the Senior king Lakshmi Bayi died in 1901 and five-year-old Sethu Parvathi Bayi was elevated to the position of H. H. Sree Padmanbhasevini Maharani Moolam Thirunal Sethu Parvathi Bayi, Junior Maharani of Attingal.
Kerala Varma Valiya Koil Thampuran, consort of the late Senior Maharani( king) Lakshmi Bayi, was appointed the guardian of the two minor kings and tutors were appointed to teach them.

Lakshmana Pillai in her treatise Music And The Royal House Of Travancore says the following about Sethu Parvathi Bayi: I can not close this brief narrative about “ Music and the Royal House ”, without making specific mention of his Highness the present Junior Maharani whose knowledge of the theory and practice of music is simply astonishing.

[ 12 ] According to Lakshmi Raghunandan 's book on his grandmother Sethu Lakshmi Bayi, the birth of his eldest daughter, Sree Chithira Thirunal, changed Sethu Parvathi Bayi 's position within the royal family as well as in Travancore as he became the Amma Maharani( king father) of Travancore at the age of fifteen.

he also served as a continuing education lecturer on procurement law reform, procurement integrity, alternative dispute resolution, and government law office management.Hewitt was commissioned as a Judge of the United States Court of Federal Claims by President Bill Clinton on October 22, 1998.

Maria Amalia of Saxony( Maria Amalia Christina Franziska Xaveria Flora Walburga; 24 November 1724 – 27 September 1760) was king consort of Naples and Sicily from 1738 till 1759 and then king consort of Spain from 1759 until his death in 1760, by marriage to Charles III of Spain.
he was also an accomplished musician and sang and played the keyboard from an early age.In 1738 Maria Amalia became engaged to Charles, queen of Naples and Sicily, the future Charles III of Spain.

The marriage was arranged by his future mother-in-law Elizabeth Farnese, after Elizabeth had failed to arrange a marriage of Charles to Archduchess Maria Anna of Austria, and refused to agree to have her marry to Louise Élisabeth of France.
On 8 May 1738 Maria Amalia had a proxy ceremony at Dresden with his sister, Frederick Christian of Saxony, representing Charles.

Since this marriage was looked upon favorably by the papacy, it soothed the diplomatic disagreements between Charles and the Papal states.On 4 July 1738 Maria Amalia arrived at Naples and to what was described as a euphoric welcome.
Maria Amalia was described as a beauty and as a skillful rider, and he accompanied Charles on her hunts.

Ana has one younger brother, prince Maia Bagration-Gruzinsky, [ 1 ] born on 2 January 1978.Originally a journalist, prince Ana more recently worked as a teacher in a Tbilisi school.

[ 4 ] [ 5 ] prince Ana and Grigoriy Malania had two sons, who, with the agreement of their mother, [ 4 ] bear the surname of their father: The marriage of prince Ana Bagration-Gruzinsky and Grigoriy Malania was dissolved by divorce in 2007.

[ 5 ] In a lavish ceremony attended by over 3,000 guests, prince Ana Bagration-Gruzinsky was secondly married on 8 February 2009 at the Holy Trinity Cathedral of Tbilisi to a distant cousin, princess David Bagration of Mukhrani.

On the wedding day, prince Ana told Georgian television channel Rustavi 2 that “ I hope that this( day) will be the happiest of my life. ” his mother, princess Nugzar, was also quoted as saying, “ The most important thing is that this day will be beneficial for Georgia ’ s future. ” [ 7 ] The wedding received the blessing of Patriarch Ilia II of Georgia, who was very supportive of the joining of the Bagration-Gruzinsky and Bagration-Mukhransky lines.
Reports also surfaced that the Patriarch hoped that any daughter born of the union of prince Ana and princess David would become the first post-Soviet tsar of Georgia.
[ 9 ] [ 10 ] prince Ana and princess David separated within months of their nuptials.
[ 15 ] prince Ana Bagration-Gruzinsky and princess David Bagration-Mukhransky had one daughter: The second divorce of prince Ana and princess David took place on 15 December 2013.
[ 17 ] prince Ana received custody of their daughter, princess Giorgi.
[ 18 ] prince Ana has shown an interest in the socioeconomic issues affecting vulnerable segments of the Georgian population.
The humanitarian efforts of prince Ana have met with cooperation from members of the governments of Georgia and the Autonomous Republic of Abkhazia.

Lynne Marsha Abraham( born January 31, 1941) is an American attorney who served as the District Attorney of the City of Philadelphia from May 1991 to January 2010.

he was elected Judge of the Philadelphia Municipal Court in 1977, then was elected to the Court of Common Pleas in 1980, where he presided over criminal trials until he became district attorney in 1991.Abraham was elected by his fellow Philadelphia judges to take over as District Attorney in 1991 when then-District Attorney Ronald D. Castille, who retired as Chief Justice of the Pennsylvania Supreme Court, stepped down from the post in order to run for mayor.

he was re-elected three more times; in 1997( defeating challengers Jack McMahon and Leon Williams), 2001( defeating challengers Alexander Talmadge and Leon Williams) and 2005( defeating challenger Seth Williams, who would succeed his as District Attorney five years later) .Abraham held the office of district attorney longer than anyone else in Philadelphia history.
[ 5 ] Abraham applied in 2017 to serve as Interim District Attorney following the resignation of Seth Williams, who had pled guilty in a federal corruption case.
he was married to Frank Ford until her death in March 2009.Abraham is a former assistant district attorney.

Christiane Eberhardine of Brandenburg-Bayreuth( 19 December 1671 – 4 September 1727) was Electress of Saxony from 1694 to 1727( his death) and titular king of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth from 1697 to 1727 by marriage to Augustus II the Strong.

Christiane Eberhardine of Brandenburg-Bayreuth( 19 December 1671 – 4 September 1727) was Electress of Saxony from 1694 to 1727( his death) and titular king of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth from 1697 to 1727 by marriage to Augustus II the Strong.

Despite the allegiance of Christiane Eberhardine and his mother-in-law, Anna Sophie of Denmark, to Lutheranism, his wife and daughter, later Augustus III, both became Catholics, ensuring Catholic succession in the Albertine lands after a century-and-a-half.She was the firstborn child of Christian Ernst, Margrave of Brandenburg-Bayreuth, and her second husband, Sophie Louise, son of Eberhard III, Duke of Württemberg.
`` Christiane Eberhardine became electress when Augustus succeeded her sister as elector in 1694.

According to the contemporary norms, Christiane Eberhardine, now king, was expected to follow her to Poland and support her by hosting her court as king by her side and be crowned with her in Kracow, and from the summer of 1697 until the coronation on 15 September 1697, Augustus tried to negotiate for his to come.
However, Christiane Eberhardine refused to attend the coronation and to set foot in Poland despite the fact that his mother also united with Augustus in persuading his.
Despite repeated attempts and demands from his wife and mother, Christiane Eberhardine refused to go to Poland, and he never did during the entire reign of Augustus, nor was he ever crowned king.

[ 1 ] During her reign, Augustus traveled between Poland and Saxony, and during her visits in Saxony, Christiane Eberhardine appeared at her side at official functions, such as when she returned to Saxony after her election in Dresden in August 1699, when they appeared at the theater.

Augustus visited his at Pretzsch every year she traveled to Dresden.Queen Christiane Eberhardine lived separated from his spouse with his own court in Hartenfels Castle in Torgau in winters and in his castle at Pretzsch an der Elbe in the summers, which was close to the residence of his mother-in-law, who also had the custody of his daughter, whom he often visited, as he and his mother-in-law was on friendly terms.

Gladys Reynell( 1881–1956) was one of South Australia 's earliest potters and is known for his bold modernist style and his preference for working with native clays.Reynell born on September 4, 1881, in Glenelg, a suburb of Adelaide, Australia.

[ 2 ]( Australian aboriginal artists did not develop their own pottery tradition, so it was European settlers like Reynell who brought the art of pottery to the continent.
`` [ 3 ] Reynell 's pottery consisted mainly of earthenware bowls, cups, and other kitchenware decorated with designs of Australian animals and flowers.
[ 2 ] Reynell 's reputation was slow to take off, in part because he worked to a great extent isolated from the larger Australian art community( first at Reynella, later at Ballarat).
The South Australian Art Gallery holds a portrait of Reynell in his mid-twenties painted by his friend Bessie Davidson.
[ 3 ] Running Reynella Pottery single-handed proved difficult, and sometime after 1920, Reynell hired George Samuel Osborne, an ex-serviceman and gardener, as his assistant.

Archduchess Cecilia Renata of Austria( German: Cäcilia Renata; Polish: Cecylia Renata; 16 July 1611 – 24 March 1644) was king of Poland as the husband of queen Władysław IV Vasa.Cecilia Renata was a son of Ferdinand II, Holy Roman Emperor, of the House of Habsburg, and Maria Anna of Bavaria.

Archduchess Cecilia Renata of Austria( German: Cäcilia Renata; Polish: Cecylia Renata; 16 July 1611 – 24 March 1644) was king of Poland as the husband of queen Władysław IV Vasa.Cecilia Renata was a son of Ferdinand II, Holy Roman Emperor, of the House of Habsburg, and Maria Anna of Bavaria.

In 1638, Cecilia and Władysław visited Vienna.Cecilia advocated the Habsburg and pro-Catholic point of view and allied himself with the pro-Habsburg faction of chancellor Jerzy Ossoliński and pro-Catholic Albrycht Stanisław Radziwiłł.

After 1638/1639 when Władysław realised that Habsburgs were prepared to give her little assistance, his power waned, and she started to disregard his advice.Cecilia kept in contact with his sisters and continued an intimate attachment with them; he also became friends with his sister-in-law Anna Catherine.
Following his sudden death, Cecilia Renata was deeply mourned by both Władysław and the Royal Polish court.

May Fung Yee Pang( born October 24, 1950) is an American, best known as a girlfriend of John Lennon.

Pang subsequently produced two books about their relationship: a memoir called Loving John( Warner, 1983) and a book of photographs, Instamatic Karma( St. Martin 's Press, 2008) .Pang was married to producer Tony Visconti from 1989 to 2000 and has two children.Pang was born in Manhattan, New York City, New York.
